Chapter 12 - ELECTRICAL CODE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 00-27, adopted Sept. 5, 2000, amended Ch. 12, in its entirety, to read as herein set out. Prior to inclusion of said ordinance, Ch. 12 pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table.   Subsequently, Ord. No. 2012-11, § 1, adopted May 1, 2012, provides that the term "electrical inspector" shall be replaced with the term "code official." See also § 12-22. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-11, § 1, adopted May 1, 2012, provides that the term "electrical inspector" shall be replaced with the term "code official." See also § 12-22. 

Sec. 12-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivatives shall be construed as set out in this section. 
    Apprentice electrician means any person engaged in learning under, and assisting a master electrician or a journeyman electrician, or both, as his principal occupation. 
    Authorized person means any person registered under the provisions of this chapter to do the work as permitted under the specific provisions of this chapter. 
    Electrical construction means all work and materials used in installing, maintaining or extending a system of electrical wiring and all appurtenances, apparatus or equipment used in connection therewith, inside or outside or attached to any building, structure, lot or premises. 
    Electrical contractor/master electrician means any person engaged in the business of installing or altering, by contract, electrical conductors or equipment. It shall include any authorized person, whether actually doing electrical work or not, and any authorized person who subcontracts to do such work, but does not include bona fide employees by such contractor to do or supervise such work. Said individual (twenty-one (21) years or older) must possess the necessary qualifications, training, and technical knowledge to plan, layout, and supervise the installation, maintenance, and extension of the electrical conductors and equipment. 
    Electrician means a person who engaged in the trade or business of electrical construction and who is qualified under the terms and provisions of this chapter. 
    Elevator contractor means any person licensed by the state who engages in the business of servicing, maintaining, installing, or altering the electrical conductors and equipment used to operate, limit or control electrically operated elevators. It shall include any authorized person, whether actually doing electrical elevator work or not, and any authorized person who subcontracts to do such work, but does not include bona fide employees employed by such contractor to do or supervise such work. 
    Escalator contractor means any person engaged in the business of servicing, maintaining, installing, or altering the electrical conductors and equipment used to operate, limit or control electrically operated escalators. It shall include any authorized person, whether actually doing electrical escalator work or not, and any authorized person who subcontracts to do such work, but does not include bona fide employees employed by such contractor to do or supervise such work. 
    Inspector means any individual who has been qualified and employed by the city as an electrical inspector. 
    Journeyman electrician means any individual who possesses the necessary qualifications, training, and technical knowledge to install, maintain, and extend electrical conductors and equipment. He shall be capable of doing such work in accordance with plans and specifications furnished him and in accordance with standard rules and regulations governing such work. He shall have three (3) years experienced as a registered apprentice electrician. 
    Lighting maintenance contractor means any individual who possesses the necessary qualifications, training, and technical knowledge to repair, operate, and replace electrical conductors and equipment in a specific building or premises. 
    Maintenance electrician means any individual who possesses the necessary qualifications, training, and technical knowledge to repair, operate, and replace electrical conductors and equipment in a specific building or premises. 
    Registered means the person has made application to the City of Eagle Pass' Building Department and has satisfied the city that he is qualified to do the work stated in the application, that he has paid the necessary registration fees to date, passed the required test, and that his name is carried in the records of the building department as a person authorized to do the electrical work for which he is registered as defined in this chapter. 
    Special permission means the written consent of the office of the electrical inspector. 
    Special ruling means a written ruling filed in the office of the electrical inspector. 
    Specialist electrician means any individual who possesses the necessary qualifications to construct, repair, install or maintain specific electrical conductors and equipment under the specific classification of electrical work for which the specialist is qualified. 
    Words used in any regulation or standard of the National Board of Fire Underwriters used as a standard of good electrical practice shall, if defined herein, have the meanings assigned them. 
    Words relating to buildings and building use, when not otherwise separately defined, shall have meanings which conform to the meanings set out in the building and zoning ordinances of the city, otherwise they shall have their usual dictionary meanings. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-2. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is the practical safeguarding of persons and of building and their contents from electrical hazards arising from the use of electricity for light, heat, power, radio, television, signaling, and for other purposes. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-3. - Scope. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall apply to all installations of, and work done on electrical conductors, fittings, devices, motors, appliances, fixtures, hereinafter referred to as "electrical equipment," within or on public and private building and premises, with exceptions as provided herein. 
    On all installations of electrical conductors or equipment hereafter made on all existing installations which are altered, all work shall be done in a manner that will conform with the requirements for a sufficient and safe electrical system as hereinafter described. 
    Repair and maintenance work shall be such that if any electrical conductors or equipment are removed and later replaced, they shall be placed in a manner which conforms with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-4. - Public utilities. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to installations used by electricity supply, electric railway, or communication agencies in the generation, transmission or distribution of electricity or for the operation of street railways, signals or the transmission of intelligence when located within or on buildings or premises used exclusively by such an agency or on public thoroughfares; provided, however that such agencies excepted are operating under a franchise agreement with the city and are under the jurisdiction of the supervisor of public utilities or an officer of similar general jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-5. - Radio and television stations. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall apply to all electrical equipment used for power to supply radio and television transmitting equipment. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-6. - Federal buildings. 
    Buildings which are owned, leased, and/or occupied by the United States Government shall be subject to all of the provisions of this chapter including inspections and the payment of fees. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-7. - State, county, public agency, and city buildings. 
    Buildings and structures owned by the state shall not be subject to the provisions of this chapter. However, buildings and structures owned by the county, the Eagle Pass Independent School District, Southwest Texas Junior College, Rio Grande College, the Eagle Pass Housing Authority, and the city shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter, but shall be exempt from the payment of maintenance-related permit fees. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000; Ord. No. 2012-11, § 1, 5-1-2012; Ord. No. 2015-10, § 1, 5-19-2015) 
Sec. 12-8. - Other buildings. 
    All other buildings within this city shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-9. - Responsibility for safe work. 
    This chapter shall not be construed to relieve from or lessen the responsibility or liability of any party owning, operating, controlling or installing any electrical equipment for damages to persons or property caused by any defect herein, nor shall the city be held as assuming any such liability by reason of the inspection or reinspection authorized herein; or the certificate of approval issued as herein provided; or by reason of the approval or disapproval of any equipment authorized herein. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-10. - Energizing customer's service entrance permanently. 
    Only authorized employees of the local serving utility shall be permitted to make the connection between the local serving utility company's service conductors and the customer's service entrance conductors. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Secs. 12-11-12-13. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- It should be noted that the provisions of former §§ 12-11-12-13, which pertained to the national electrical code, have been deleted as being superseded with the adoption of the International Building Code by Ord. No. 02-02, adopted Jan. 8, 2002. The user's attention is directed to Art. II of Ch. 8 for current building and related code provisions. See also the Code Comparative Table for a detailed analysis of inclusion of said Ord. No. 02-02. 
Secs. 12-14-12-21. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-11, § 1, adopted May 1, 2012, provides that the term "electrical inspector" shall be replaced with the term "code official." See also § 12-22. 

Sec. 12-22. - Creation of enforcement agency; code official. 
    The planning department is hereby created as the enforcement agency for the administration of the electrical code, and the official in charge thereof known as the code official. The planning director shall serve as the code official for purposes of the administration of this code. The term "electrical inspector" shall be replaced with the term "code official." 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000; Ord. No. 2012-11, § 1, 5-1-2012) 
Sec. 12-23. - Other electrical inspectors authorized. 
    The employment of electrical inspectors for the inspection of electrical installations, as provided for in this chapter, shall be authorized by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-24. - Appointment of inspectors. 
    The electrical inspectors shall be appointed by the city manager. Appointment and removal of any such person shall be in accordance with the rules and regulations of the city government. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-25. - Conflict of interests. 
    It shall be unlawful for the electrical inspectors to engage in the business of selling, installing, or maintaining of electrical conductors, devices, appliances, apparatus, or equipment, and they shall have no financial interest in any concern engaged in such business in any areas under the city's jurisdiction at any time while employed by the city. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-26. - General duties of electrical inspector generally. 
    It shall be the duty of the electrical inspector to enforce the provisions of this chapter. He shall, upon approval of the applications, grant permits for the installation, extension, or alteration of electrical conductors and equipment, and shall make inspections of all electrical work, as provided for in this chapter. He shall keep complete records of all permits issued, inspections and re-inspections made and other official work performed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. He shall verify that all appliances meet Underwriters' Laboratories, Inc. specifications and requirements, and shall keep on file a list of inspected electrical appliances issued by Underwriters' Laboratories, Inc., which list shall be accessible for public reference during regular office hours. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-27. - Liability of inspectors. 
    Where action is taken by the electrical inspectors to enforce the provisions of this chapter, such be done in the name of, and on behalf of the city, and the inspectors in so acting for the city shall not render themselves personally liable for any damage which may occur to persons or property as a result of any act committed in good faith in the discharge of their duties. Any suit brought against any inspector by reason thereof, shall be defended by the city attorney until final termination of the proceedings contained therein. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-28. - Enforcement power of inspectors. 
    The electrical inspectors shall have full power to enforce and shall have the right to issue citations to any person who violates any of the regulations of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-29. - Assistance from police. 
    Whenever, in the opinion of an electrical inspector, it shall be necessary to call upon the police department for assistance in stopping work, he shall have the authority to do so; and it shall be the duty of any member of the police department, when called upon by the inspector, to act immediately in giving the required assistance. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-30. - Right of entry. 
    The electrical inspectors shall have the right during reasonable hours to enter any building or premises in the discharge of their official duties, or for the purpose of making any inspection, re-inspection or test of the electrical equipment or installation contained therein. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-31. - Correction of dangerous equipment. 
    When any electrical equipment is found by an inspector to be dangerous to persons or property because it is defective or improperly installed, the person owning the electrical equipment shall be notified in writing and shall have any changes or repairs made as required by the electrical inspector which will place such equipment in safe condition. If such work is not completed as specified by the inspector in the notice, the electrical inspector shall have the authority to disconnect or order the disconnection of electrical service to the dangerous electrical equipment. In cases of emergency, when necessary for safety to persons or property, or when electrical equipment may interfere with the work of the fire department, the senior officer of the fire department at the site shall have the authority to immediately cause the disconnection of any electrical equipment. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-32. - Service of notices. 
    When any order or notice is issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter to any person who cannot be found after a reasonable search, then such order or notice may be served by posting it in a conspicuous place upon the premises where the defects are alleged to exist. Such posting of the notice shall be considered equivalent to personal service of such order or notice. An order sent by registered mail in a sealed envelope with postage prepaid and directed to the last known address of the electrical contractor, owner, lessee or occupant of the premises shall be equivalent to personal service of such order. Electrical inspectors are hereby empowered to attach to electrical cabinets and equipment an official notice or seal to prevent use of electricity. It shall be unlawful for any other person to place or attache such seal, or to break, change, destroy, tear, mutilate, cover, or otherwise deface or injure such official notice or seal posted by an electrical inspector. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-33. - Special rulings. 
    If a special ruling by the electrical inspector is necessary to govern electrical construction not covered by this chapter or by the National Electrical Code, whereby all wiring for similar types of electrical construction will be changed in the future, such special ruling shall first be approved by the board of electricians. A copy of such ruling shall be filed in the office of the electrical inspector, and additional copies shall be sent to each registered electrical contractor. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-34. - Special permissions. 
    The regulations of the National Electrical Code may be modified or waived by special permission in specific cases where such modification or waiver is reasonable and does not differ from the intent of this chapter. Such permission shall in all cases be obtained from the electrical inspector and confirmed in writing. A copy of the permission shall be filed in the office of the electrical inspector and additional copies shall be sent to each registered contractor. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Secs. 12-35-12-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ELECTRICIANS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-11, § 1, adopted May 1, 2012, provides that the term "electrical inspector" shall be replaced with the term "code official." See also § 12-22. 

Sec. 12-46. - Registration and license required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person who is not registered and licensed as a qualified electrician in accordance with the provisions of this chapter to engage in the business of electrical construction or to make any repairs, alterations, additions, or changes to any existing system of electrical conductors, wiring, apparatus, or equipment within the limits of the city except as otherwise provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-47. - Exceptions from registration or license requirements. 
    The following classes of work may be carried out by persons who are not electricians: 
(1)  The replacement of lamps, fuses or equivalent and the connection of portable devices to suitable receptacles which have been permanently installed. 
(2)  The installation, alteration or repairing of any wiring, devices, or equipment for the operation of signal or the transmission of intelligence, where such wiring, devices, appliances, or equipment operates at a voltage not exceeding fifty (50) volts between conductors and do not include generating or transforming equipment. 
(3)  The installation, alteration or repair of electric wiring, devices, appliances and equipment installed by or for an electrical public service corporation operating under a franchise from the city when for the use of such corporation in the generation, transmission, distribution, or metering of the electrical energy or for the use of such a corporation in the operation of street railways, signals, or the transmitting of intelligences. 
(4)  Any work involved in the manufacture or test of electrical materials, devices, appliances, or apparatus, but not including any installation of wiring other than that required for testing purposes if such equipment as complete is approved by the electrical inspector before it is installed or used within the city. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-48. - False representations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to falsely represent himself as an electrician of any class set out in this article or to use the words "electrical contractor," "master electrician," "electrician," or words of similar import or meaning on signs, cards, stationery, or by any other manner whatsoever, unless said person is properly registered and licensed within the meaning of the words used as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-49. - Classification of licenses (registration). 
    Electrical licenses (registration) shall be in the classifications listed below: 
(1)  Electrical contractor/master electrician. 
(2)  Lighting maintenance contractor. 
(3)  Elevator and escalator contractor (state licensed). 
(4)  Journeyman electrician. 
(5)  Maintenance electrician. 
(6)  Fire alarm contractor. 
(7)  Apprentice electrician. 
    A person licensed in one of these classifications shall be permitted to perform the work of that classification as hereinafter defined. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-50. - Application for registration. 
(a)  To secure a certificate of registration as a qualified and competent electrician in any of the classes set out in this article, an application shall be made in writing and addressed to the building department. The application shall show the applicant's name and such other information as may be prescribed by the department, and shall be made out on forms available in the building department. 
(b)  Applicants for a certificate as electrical contractor, lighting maintenance contractor, elevator and escalator contractor, or building maintenance operator shall file with the application an affidavit, setting forth the names of the person or persons who are the owners of the business or who are the officers of the firm who own the business and the name and address of the person who shall be responsible for the business. The applicants shall appear in person if requested by the building department and be examined as provided in this chapter. 
(c)  Applicants for an examination as master electrician shall show evidence as being qualified in the electrical field or a graduate of a recognized technical school or college, and shall file with the application an affidavit showing that such applicant is not less than twenty-one (21) years of age and shall have had at least two (2) years experience as a journeyman electrician. Applicants shall apply at the building department in person and be examined as provided in this chapter. 
(d)  Applicants for a certificate as maintenance electrician or specialist electrician shall apply in person at the building department and be examined as prescribed in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-51. - Proof of qualification for registration. 
    Before any applicant for master electrician or electrical contractor is considered for registration, he shall show evidence that he has successfully passed the examination as prepared and given by the city. 
NOTE: ANY MASTER AND JOURNEYMAN ELECTRICIAN HAVING BEEN LICENSED BY THE CITY OF EAGLE PASS AND OPERATING AS SUCH AS OF SEPTEMBER 14, 2000 AND IS IN GOOD STANDING WITH THE BUILDING DEPARTMENT ARE EXEMPTED FROM THIS SECTION. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000; Ord. No. 01-04, § 1, 1-16-2001; Ord. No. 04-38, § 1, 11-24-2004) 
Sec. 12-52. - Reexamination. 
    If an applicant for a master electrician license fails to pass his first examination, he shall not be examined again prior to the expiration of two (2) calendar months from the date of said first examination. If the applicant fails to pass the second examination, he shall not be examined again prior to the expiration of six (6) calendar months from the date of his last such examination. If the applicant fails to pass the third examination, he shall not be examined again prior to the expiration of twelve (12) calendar months from the date of his last such examination. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-53. - Fees for examination and registration. 
    The fees for examination shall be payable to the City of Eagle Pass. Each applicant for a certificate of registration (hereinafter referred as license) shall pay to the City of Eagle Pass the examination fee as specified. A separate fee shall be paid each time an applicant takes an examination. An applicant who fails to take the examination following the date of his application shall forfeit his fee unless an excuse is obtained prior to the examination date and provided a new application is filed before the next regular examination. 
    The annual registration fee shall be paid before the issuance of a license of registration. The fiscal year for the payment of fees shall begin on January 1, and shall end on December 31, of the same year. In case of new registrations after July 1 of any year, the annual fee shall be one-half (1/2) of the amount shown in Table 1, provided that renewal fees shall not be so pro-rated. 
Table 1: Registration Fees 
(1) Electrical contractor/master electrician $100.00 $65.00 (2) Lighting maintenance contractor 100.00 65.00 (3) Elevator and escalator contractor 100.00 65.00 (4) Maintenance electrician 100.00 65.00 (5) Journeyman electrician 100.00 65.00 (6) Fire alarm contractor 100.00 65.00 (7) Apprentice electrician 75.00 50.00  
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-54. - Bond. 
    Each person, before receiving his license or renewal license as master electrician or as provided in this chapter, shall make, execute and deliver to the City of Eagle Pass' Building Department a corporate surety bond in the principal amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) payable to the City of Eagle Pass and submit to the city proof of general liability insurance for an amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) conditioned upon review by the city attorney and upon compliance with the provisions and regulations of this chapter and of the National Electrical Code, herein adopted for electrical work within the city. Such bond shall be executed and such liability insurance shall be submitted on a yearly basis. 
NOTE: The bond and liability insurance requirements also apply to any master electrician currently operating under a license issued by the City of Eagle Pass. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000; Ord. No. 01-04, § 2, 1-16-2001) 
Sec. 12-55. - Contractors-Individuals. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of electrical contractor, lighting maintenance contractor, elevator and escalator contractor, or building maintenance operator, without being licensed in the manner hereinafter set forth, and without indicating the name by which the business shall be known. 
(b)  No electrical contractor shall establish, maintain, or advertise a place of business at any location within the city under any name other than that licensed with the building department. Any person desiring to engage in the business of electrical contracting, or lighting maintenance contracting, shall make application for license at the building department. Upon the filing of such application in proper form, and the payment of the license fee as provided for in this article, the electrical inspector shall register the applicant as an electrical contractor, or lighting maintenance contractor, and shall issue to the applicant a certificate of registration, provided he has qualified, and has registered the proper address of his established place of business. 
(c)  An electrical contractor's certificate shall entitle the holder thereof to engage in the business of, and to secure permits for the installation, addition, alteration, servicing, replacing, removing, or repair of any electrical conductors, apparatus, appliances, devices and equipment. 
(d)  If such electrical contractor shall engage in the installation, alteration or repair of any elevator and escalator equipment, then he shall have his contractor's certificate approved for such work. 
(e)  Any person engaged in the electrical contracting business shall be a qualified master electrician and be responsible for carrying out the provisions of this chapter in its entirety. 
(f)  A lighting maintenance contractor's license shall entitle the holder thereof to engage in the business of repair and maintenance of lighting fixtures only, and such person engaged in the lighting maintenance contracting business shall have continuously in his employ a qualified journeyman who shall have active supervision over, and be responsible for carrying out lighting maintenance. The electrical inspector shall be notified in writing in the event the journeyman electrician is replaced by another journeyman electrician who has qualified as required by this article. An elevator and escalator contractor's license shall entitle the holder thereof to engage in the business of, and to secure permits for the installation, repairs, and alteration of any electrical wiring and equipment connected with the installation of electrical elevators and escalators. The actual work of installation shall be under the direct supervision of a qualified master, journeyman, or specialist elevator and escalator electrician. 
(g)  The building department is hereby authorized to withhold inspections and the issuance of permits to any licensed electrical contractor, master electrician, etc. who: 
(1)  Fails to correct any defect, error, or deficiency in any work installed under the authority of an electrical permit within ten (10) calendar days after written notification thereof from the building department. 
(2)  Fails to pay any just indebtedness to the city for inspection fees charged for specific permits. 
(h)  Every electrical contractor, lighting maintenance contractor, and elevator and escalator contractor shall have an established place of business. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-56. - Same-Firm or corporation. 
(a)  Any person holding an electrical contractor's license shall be a qualified master electrician. 
(b)  Any person who has been appointed or employed as a master electrician by a licensed electrical contractor, shall register with the electrical inspector in writing on a form to be furnished by the electrical inspector's office. When an applicant has complied with the requirements of this article, the electrical inspector shall certify him as a master electrician to a specific licensed electrical contractor by placing his name on the contractor's registration certificate and by identification card issued to the registered master electrician. 
(c)  The master electrician shall perform the work or supervise and direct the installation, alteration, repair, and maintenance of electrical conductors and equipment authorized by permits issued under the authority of this chapter. Whenever a master electrician shall leave or be discharged from the employ of any person who is required by this chapter to appoint or employ a master electrician, a notice in writing thereof shall be given immediately by both the employer and the master electrician to the electrical inspector's office, and the permit privileges of such a person, shall, without further order or action, stand suspended until the employment or appointment and registration of another master electrician as provided for in this article. When a master electrician has not acted in the capacity of a master electrician or in a supervisory position on electrical work in any city for a continuous period of two (2) years, he may be required to be re-examined before being certified as a registered master electrician. 
(d)  No master electrician shall be permitted to use his license of registration in order to qualify more than one electrical contractor's license at any time. 
(e)  The master electrician, after having passed the required examination, shall be granted a license, showing that he has the necessary qualifications to install or direct the installation of electrical conductors, devices, apparatus, and equipment. It shall be unlawful for any master electrician to permit his name to be used, or to knowingly permit himself to be held out as the officer or employee in a supervisory capacity of any person holding an electrical contractor's license unless he is, in fact, an officer or employee and does, in fact, supervise the installation of electrical work performed by such persons. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-57. - Registration of journeyman electricians. 
(a)  Applicants shall be not less than eighteen (18) years of age and shall have had at least three (3) years' experience in the installation, alteration, repair, and maintenance of electrical conductors, and equipment or an equivalent experience thereto. 
(b)  The master electrician and/or electrical contractor shall designate the journeyman electricians in his employment. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-58. - Registration of maintenance electrician. 
(a)  Applicant may be a registered master electrician or may apply for registration as a maintenance electrician. 
(b)  Each applicant not holding a master electrician license shall be required to answer a reasonable number of questions in writing as provided by the building department to show that he has sufficient knowledge and training to perform maintenance work. 
(c)  The certificate of a maintenance electrician shall bear the name of the person by whom the holder thereof is regularly employed, and the place of employment, and shall become null and void and re-registration shall be required each time a change is made in employer and place of employment. 
(d)  A maintenance electrician's license shall entitle the holder thereof to engage himself in the employ of any person holding an electrical building maintenance operator's license under the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-59. - Registration of specialist electrician. 
(a)  Applicant may be a registered master electrician or may apply for registration as a specialist electrician in the following class: 
Elevator and escalator electrician (state licensed) 
(b)  Each applicant not holding a master electrician license may be required to answer a reasonable number of questions in writing to the building department to show that he has sufficient knowledge and training to perform the work for the class of electrical specialist applied for. A specialist electrician's license shall entitle the holder to engage himself in the employ of any person holding a license to do the work for which the specialist has been qualified. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-60. - Expiration of license. 
    Every license provided for in this article shall expire at midnight on the thirty-first day of December, following the date of its issuance. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-61. - Renewal of registration. 
    Every license provided for in this article shall expire at midnight on December 31, following the date of its issuance, and shall be renewed by the building department upon application and upon the payment to the city of the required renewal fee; provided, however, that if during the preceding year the applicant has been convicted of a violation of this chapter, it will be necessary for him to be re-examined by the City of Eagle Pass. Should any license lapse for more than thirty (30) days, the holder shall be considered as a new applicant, and the initial registration fee shall be charged. 
    Should the holder of a license take up another occupation or profession or otherwise indicate that he has abandoned his occupation as an electrician or contractor, even though he may apply for a license each year, he may be required to be examined every two (2) years in order to maintain his registration. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-62. - License not transferable. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to lend, rent or transfer his license or any rights therein contained to any other person, and for any person to make use of any such rights which are not actually his own. It shall be unlawful for any person other than the electrical inspector or his inspector to alter or amend in any manner such license. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-63. - Display of license. 
    Every holder of a license as an electrical contractor, lighting maintenance contractor, elevator and escalator contractor, and building maintenance operator shall display his license in a conspicuous place in his principal place of business. Every holder of a license as a registered master, journeyman, maintenance or specialist electrician shall carry his license on his person at all times while doing electrical work and shall produce and exhibit it when requested by any inspector from the building department. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-64. - Supervision required. 
    In the actual work of installing, maintaining, altering or repairing any electric conductor or equipment for which a permit is required, there shall be present and in direct supervision a qualified electrician of the proper classification. Should it come to the notice of the electrical inspector or his inspectors that such supervision and control are not being maintained, the inspector may order the work to be discontinued and the person to whom the permit has been issued shall discontinue further work until proper supervision has been employed or supplied; provided, that nothing herein shall be construed as prohibiting the employment of apprentices or unskilled laborers assisting a person duly registered and qualified under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-65. - Revocation of license, appeal. 
    If the holder of any license willfully violates any provision of this chapter, is incompetent to comply with such provisions, or such person has been found guilty of violating any such provisions, the electrical inspector may at any time give notice in writing to the holder of such license that said license has been revoked and canceled. Said notice of revocation or cancellation of said license shall become final after the expiration of ten (10) days from the date of service of same upon the holder of said license, unless on or before the expiration of said ten (10) days the holder of said license shall file with the building department, a written appeal addressed to the board of electricians in which it is requested that said board grant a hearing to the holder of such license upon the question of whether or not the license issued by the building department shall be canceled and revoked. Said appeal, if made and filed as prescribed herein, shall operate as a stay or postponement of said revocation and cancellation of the license issued, until such time as the board of electricians shall grant a hearing and make a final adjudication upon the question of whether or not such license should be canceled, such hearing to be held within fifteen (15) days after the date of the filing of such appeal. The judgment or decision of a majority of said board shall be final and conclusive as to all parties. At such hearing before the board, the electrical inspector may be represented by the city attorney. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Secs. 12-66-12-77. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BOARD OF ELECTRICIANS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-11, § 2, adopted May 1, 2012, repealed the former Art. IV, §§ 12-78-12-86, and enacted a new Art. IV, § 12-78, as set out herein. The former Art. IV pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000; Ord. No. 05-04, 2-15-2005; Ord. No. 06-16, 8-15-2006.   Additionally, § 1 of Ord. No. 2012-11 provides that the term "electrical inspector" shall be replaced with the term "code official." See also § 12-22. 

Sec. 12-78. - [Building Codes Council.] 
A.  The City of Eagle Pass Building Codes Council (BCC) is hereby created and shall hear and decide appeals of orders, decisions or determinations made by the code official relative to the application and interpretation of this code. Board appointments shall confirmed by the city council, and board members shall serve at the pleasure of the city council. 
B.  An appeal shall be based upon a claim that (a) the true intent of the electrical code has been incorrectly interpreted, (b) the provisions of the electrical code do not fully apply, or (c) an equally good or better form of construction is proposed. 
C.  The BCC is not authorized to waive the requirements of the electrical code. 
D.  Appeals of orders, decisions, or determinations made by the code official relative to the application and/or interpretation of the various codes adopted herein shall be filed with the code official in writing within thirty (30) days of the date of the order, decision, or determination, together with the one hundred fifty dollar ($150.00) appeal processing fee. Failure to appeal within thirty (30) working days of written notification of action or determination shall waive any right to an administrative determination of the matter. 
E.  Except for any action undertaken pursuant to City of Eagle Pass Code of Ordinances Chapter 8 governing unsafe structures and equipment, the enforcement of any notice and order by the code official shall be stayed until final determination of the appeal is made by the BCC or a court of law under judicial appeal. 
F.  The appeal hearing process shall conform to Section 20 of City of Eagle Pass Code of Ordinances Appendix A. 
(Ord. No. 2012-11, § 2, 5-1-2012) 
Secs. 12-79-12-86. - Reserved. 
Secs. 12-87-12-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PERMITS AND INSPECTIONS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-11, § 1, adopted May 1, 2012, provides that the term "electrical inspector" shall be replaced with the term "code official." See also § 12-22. 

Sec. 12-101. - Permits required. 
    It shall be unlawful to commence, begin, or proceed with the installation, or cause to be installed, electrical conductors or equipment within or on any building, structure or premises publicly or privately owned or to make or cause to be made alterations in or addition to, electrical conductors or equipment until an electrical permit has been obtained as herein provided. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-102. - Exceptions. 
    No electrical permit shall be required for the following electrical work: 
(1)  The replacement of lamps, fuses or the connection of portable electrical equipment to permanently installed receptacle. 
(2)  The installation of electrical conductors or equipment for or by a public utility in the generation, transmission, sale and use of electrical energy or in the transmission of intelligence as outlined in its franchise. 
(3)  Work involved in the manufacturing, repair or testing of electrical equipment or apparatus in the course of manufacture. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-103. - Temporary connections. 
    Nothing herein contained shall prohibit the restoration on a temporary basis of electrical service under emergency conditions before the obtaining of a permit when approval of such work is obtained from the electrical inspector prior to the commencing of the work and inspection of such work is done as provided herein. In such cases a permit shall be obtained immediately for such work, but in no case to exceed forty-eight (48) hours from such installation. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-104. - Starting work without permit. 
    The electrical inspector is empowered to stop at once electrical work which has been begun without a permit having been secured in violation of the provisions of this article, and to order any and all persons engaged therein to stop and desist therefrom until permits are secured. Such action shall not defer any other penalties which may be imposed for the violation of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-105. - Responsibility of owner, occupant, etc. 
    The owner, agent, and/or lessee of the building or structure wherein or whereon any work is being, or to be, done under the provisions of this chapter shall determine that electrical permits are obtained as provided herein, by a properly licensed person, before work is started, for all electrical work performed on the premises, and shall be subject to the penalties provided fro the violation of this chapter for failure to do so. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-106. - Signs, elevators and escalators. 
    An electrical permit shall be secured for the installation of circuits and/or feeders which are provided for the supplying of electrical energy to a sign. A permit shall be secured for all electrical changes, installations and revisions that are done on electrical elevators and escalators. A permit shall not be required when electrical equipment on electrical elevators and escalators is being maintained by elevator and escalator contractors by repairs or replacement of any kind. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-107. - Classes of permits. 
    There shall be three (3) classes of permits for electrical work as follows: 
(1)  Specific permits. 
(2)  Annual permits for specific premises only. 
(3)  Annual permits for lighting maintenance contractor. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-108. - Application for permits-Generally. 
    Separate application for permit for each installation describing the work to be done, shall be made to the electrical inspector by the person installing the work. The application shall be accompanied by such information as may be necessary to determine whether the installation as described will be in conformity with the requirements of this chapter. 
    When required by the electrical inspector, the applicant shall state the size of conductors to be used for all services, mains, feeders, and sub-feeders, size of main and sub-feeder switches and fuses, the area to be served by such conductors and the basis used in computing the required sizes of such conductors. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-109. - Same-False information. 
    The applicant for a permit required by this article shall represent that the statements contained in said application are true and correct and any misrepresentation or false statement thereon shall be grounds for revocation of the applicant's certificate of registration and cancellation of the permit issued. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-110. - Same-Deviation. 
    No deviation shall be made from the installation described in the permit without notifying the electrical inspector. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-111. - Specific permits. 
    Specific permits when issued shall apply to a specific installation, alteration, addition or replacement of electrical conductors or equipment to be done within a specific single building, structure or premises. 
    The electrical inspector shall issue a specific permit for each installation and alteration of electrical conductors or equipment where application for such permit has been made in accordance with the requirements of this chapter; provided, that no specific permit shall be issued unless the person applying for such permit is registered as an electrical contractor or elevator and escalator contractor and has in his employ, at the time the application is made, a registered electrician; and provided, further, that the inspection fees shall be paid; and provided, that the right of a home owner to secure permits shall not be denied. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-112. - Permits for specific premises only. 
    In lieu of a specific permit for each installation or alteration, a permit shall, upon application therefore, be issued to any person regularly employing one or more electricians including a licensed master electrician for the installation, alteration, and maintenance of electrical equipment in or on a specific single building, structure or premises owned or occupied by the applicant for the permit. Any person employing one or more electricians as noted herein shall keep a log of all electrical, modifications, additions, etc. prior to approval of said permit. 
    Before such permit is issued to any person, he shall file with the electrical inspector an affidavit form of application as required and furnished by the electrical inspector. The application shall contain a description of the premises on which work is to be done under the permit, and the name of the master electrician to be appointed and employed to do the work. 
    The electrical inspector shall be notified in the event the master electrician is replaced by another master electrician who has qualified as required by this chapter. If the requirements of the annual permit as herein set forth are not met, or if the work is not done in compliance with this chapter, the electrical inspector shall suspend all the rights conveyed by such permit until such time as all deficiencies have been corrected or the permit expires. Notice of such suspension shall be in writing to the person to whom the permit was issued. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-113. - Permits for lighting maintenance contractors. 
    Any person licensed as a lighting maintenance contractor shall make application for a permit at the office of the electrical inspector. The permit shall be issued in lieu of specific permits for individual locations, however, the electrical inspector shall be furnished, in writing, the address of each location where lighting maintenance work is to be done before the work is commenced. If the work is not done in compliance with the requirements of this chapter, the electrical inspector may suspend all rights conveyed by the permit until such time as all deficiencies have been corrected. Notice of such suspension shall be in writing and addressed to the person to whom the permit was issued. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-114. - Circuses, revival tents, etc. 
(a)  Circuses, carnivals, revival tents, road shows, exhibitions, concessions, tents and other installations of a similar nature that provide self-contained generating and distribution facilities shall obtain a temporary permit from the electrical inspector who shall be responsible for determining that all wiring used shall be reasonably safe to person and property and that the work is done in a manner to render it safe from fire and electrical shock. The fee for this permit shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(b)  Circuses, carnivals, revival tents, carnivals, road shows, exhibitions, concessions, tents, and other installations of a similar nature that do not provide self-contained generating equipment, shall employ a licensed electrical contractor in a supervisory capacity, who shall be responsible and obtain permits in the name of the owner, exhibitor or operator, for all electrical work done on the premises. No electrical work except that covered by section 12-47 shall be done on a service and circuit basis as covered in section 12-116. 
(c)  Portable equipment, appliance, fixtures, switchboards and feeders shall be approved as specified in section 12-156. 
(d)  Permits shall be of a temporary nature and the applicant shall state on his request the period of time the service is required and shall remove, or apply and receive a written extension of time for the wiring so approved, at the termination of the time requested. 
(e)  All wiring used in conjunction with public assembly shall be safe to persons and property and the electrical inspector shall satisfy himself that the work is done in a manner to render it safe from fire and electrical shock. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000; Ord. No. 04-36, § 7, 10-18-2004) 
Sec. 12-115. - Holiday decorations. 
    All electrical decorations installed on public property or on streets, alleys, areas, or sidewalks accessible to the public, shall be maintained during their period of operation by a licensed electrical contractor. Permits shall be obtained for each contract made to the permanent wiring of the installation stating the length of the festoon, the wattage connected, and, when requested by the electrical inspector, plans and details of the electrical installation. 
    Permits shall be limited to a specific period of time. At the termination of the period stated, or for any valid reason, in the judgment of the electrical inspector, the decorations shall be removed by the person obtaining the permit. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-116. - Permit and inspection fees. 
    Any person granted a permit for electrical installation of conductors or equipment shall pay to the city an inspection fee. 
1.  The following specific fees shall be added to a fifteen dollar ($15.00) base fee as follows: 
(a)  Temporary service pole, each device: ..... $15.00 
(b)  3-phase meter, each device: ..... $35.00 
(c)  Light and outlet receptacle, each device: ..... $0.75 
(d)  All 110-amp circuits, each device: ..... $1.25 
(e)  All 220-amp circuits, each device: ..... $2.50 
(f)  Electrical motors, each device: ..... $2.00 
2.  One mile extra-territorial jurisdiction (ETJ): ..... $30.00 
3.  Meter loop: ..... $15.00 
4.  Re-inspection: ..... $20.00 
5.  New service: ..... $15.00 
6.  Change of service: ..... $15.00 
7.  Service relocation: ..... $15.00 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000; Ord. No. 04-36, § 8, 10-18-2004; Ord. No. 2012-11, § 3, 5-1-2012) 
Sec. 12-117. - Payment of fees. 
(a)  All fees shall be due when electrical permits are issued. 
(b)  The code official shall authorize the refunding of fees as follows: 
(1)  The full amount of any fee paid hereunder which was erroneously paid or collected. 
(2)  Not more than eighty (80) percent of the permit paid when no work has been done under a permit issued in accordance with this code. 
    The building official shall not authorize the refunding of any fee paid, except upon the receipt of a written refund request submitted by the original permittee no later than one hundred eighty (180) days after the date of fee payment. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000; Ord. No. 2012-11, § 3, 5-1-2012) 
Sec. 12-118. - Doubling of fee. 
    In case any work for which a permit is required by this article is started or proceeded with prior to the obtaining of said permit, the fee for such permit shall be doubled. The payment of such doubled fee shall not relieve any person from fully complying with the requirements of this chapter in the execution of the work from other penalties prescribed herein. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-119. - Issuance of permit. 
    If the electrical inspector shall find that the electrical work described in the permit application will conform with all legal requirements, and if the applicant has complied with all provisions of this chapter, a permit for such installation shall be issued. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-120. - Unlawful issuance of permit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to secure or furnish a permit for the installation, alteration, or repair of electrical conductors or equipment to any person not entitled to such permit under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-121. - Violations of chapter not authorized. 
    The issuance of a permit under the provisions of this article shall not be taken as permission to violate any of the requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-122. - Performance of work restricted. 
    The work indicated on the application for a permit required by this article shall be performed only by the applicant, and no other person shall perform any of the electrical work shown on the application. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-123. - Wrongful use of permit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to install, alter, or repair any electrical conductors or equipment by authority of a permit issued to and for the use of some other person. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-124. - Limitation of permits. 
    Each specific permit issued by the electrical inspector under the provisions of this article shall expire by limitation and become null and void, if the work authorized by such permit has not been started within thirty (30) days from the date of the issuance of such permit, or if the work authorized by such permit is suspended or abandoned at any time for a period of thirty (30) days after the work is started. Before such work can be started again, a new permit shall be obtained. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-125. - Revocation of permits. 
    The electrical inspector shall have the right to declare a permit null and void if there has been misrepresentation of facts or of any violation of the provision of this chapter or for any other just cause. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-126. - Notice of completion of work, inspection. 
    Upon the completion of any electrical installation for which a permit has been obtained, it shall be the duty of the person making the installation to notify the electrical inspector, who shall inspect the installation within twenty-four (24) hours, exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays, and holidays, of the time such notice is given. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-127. - Procedure when work to be concealed. 
    When any electrical equipment is to be hidden from view by the permanent placement of parts of the building, the person installing the equipment shall notify the electrical inspector, and such equipment shall not be concealed until it has been inspected, approved, and authorized by the electrical inspector by written notice posted on job site, or until three (3) working days, exclusive of Saturdays, and holidays, shall have elapsed from the time of such notification. Where the concealment of electrical equipment proceeds continuously, the person installing such equipment may apply in writing to the electrical inspector for periodic inspections, but concealment of such work shall not be done until written notice has been posted on the job site. The electrical inspectors have the authority to require building contractors to open such work which in any manner conceals electrical wiring that has been closed without his knowledge or permission, and in no case shall inspectors issue clearance until satisfied that the work is in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. Inspectors shall also have the right to refuse to issue a clearance on any wiring that is concealed in such a manner that it cannot be fully determined that it has been done in accordance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-128. - Final certificate of approval. 
    When the electrical inspector finds the electrical installation to be in conformity with the provisions of this chapter, he shall issue to the person making the installation a certificate of approval, when requested, authorizing the use of the installation and connection to the supply of electricity and shall send a notice of such authorization to the agency supplying the electric service. 
    The electrical inspector shall be deemed the judge of whether the installation of electric conductors and equipment has been made in accordance with the requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-129. - Connection to installations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make connection to a supply of electricity or to supply electricity to any electrical equipment for which a permit is required, or which has been disconnected by the order of the electrical inspector, until a written certificate of approval has been issued by the electrical inspector authorizing the connection and use of such equipment; provided, however, that the electrical inspector may authorize a temporary connection in writing. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-130. - Reinspection. 
    The electrical inspector may periodically reinspect existing installations of electrical conductors and equipment. When the installation of any conductors or equipment is found to be in a dangerous or unsafe condition, the person owning, using, or operating the installation shall be notified in writing and shall make the necessary repairs or changes required to place such conductors or equipment in safe conditions and have such work completed within the period specified by the electrical inspector. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-131. - Condemnation. 
    If, in the judgement of the electrical inspector after inspection, the electric conductors, appliances or equipment in any building or structure are unsafe or dangerous to persons or property, the inspector has the authority to cause such wires or appliances to be disconnected from the source of electrical energy supplying these conductors or equipment, and may at his discretion seal the control switches form same in an open or disconnected position whereupon he shall give written notice at the site and shall also notify the electric utility company serving the premises. Thereafter, it shall be unlawful for any person to cause or permit electric current to be supplied to the electrical conductors, appliances or equipment so sealed until they shall have been made safe and the inspector shall have issued a certificate of approval to that effect. 
    When the electrical inspector condemns all or part of any electrical installation, the owner may, within five (5) days after receiving written notice thereof, file a petition in writing for review of said action of the electrical inspector by the electrical board, upon receipt of which the board shall at once proceed to determine the facts, and within five (5) days shall make a decision in accordance with their findings. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-132. - Removal of dead wires, etc. 
    It shall be the duty of the electrical inspector to cause all dead wires, unused poles or electric apparatus on the outside of buildings or in streets or alleys to be removed at the expense of the owners thereof by giving the said owners written notice. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-133. - Interference. 
    It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to, in any manner change or alter electrical conductors or equipment in or on any building. If in the course of the erection of a building or structure, electrical conductors or equipment are in such position as to interfere with the erection or completion of the structure, notice shall be immediately given to owner and/or authorized person installing the electrical conductors or equipment, and the needed change shall be made by such authorized person. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Secs. 12-134-12-146. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - ELECTRICAL CODE[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-11, § 1, adopted May 1, 2012, provides that the term "electrical inspector" shall be replaced with the term "code official." See also § 12-22. 

Sec. 12-147. - Adopted. 
    2014 edition of the National Electric Code, is hereby adopted, as the electrical code for the City of Eagle Pass. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000; Ord. No. 2015-10, § 2, 5-19-2015; Ord. No. 2016-13, § 2, 3-22-2016) 
Sec. 12-148. - Local restrictions. 
    The following provisions shall prevail and be controlling within the city in the event of any conflict therewith and the provisions of the electrical code adopted by the provisions of this article: 
(1)  Minimum size of conductors: Whether solid or stranded shall not be smaller than twenty (20) amp rated, except for control circuits, flexible cords, fixture wire and signal circuits. 
(2)  Open wiring in (or on) insulators: Shall be permitted only by special permission. 
(3)  Concealed knob and tube wiring: Shall not be permitted in any installation. 
(4)  Metal clad cable: Types "MC" and "AC" cable shall not be approved for installation in concealed locations. 
(5)  Nonmetallic sheathed cable: Shall be limited to single-family dwellings and multiple-family dwellings. 
(6)  Service entrance cable shall not be used for meter services. 
(7)  Underground feeder and branch circuit cable, Type "UP": Shall follow the same regulations as per exception Number 5. 
(8)  Service entrance cable, Type "USE": Shall not be approved for direct burial installations. 
(9)  Minimum groundling electrode shall be five-eighths ( 5/8 ) inch by eight (8) feet copper clad. 
(10)  Temporary power poles and temporary power and light permits shall expire at the end of ninety (90) days or at the completion of work for which it was issued whichever occurs first. 
(11)  State health regulations. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-149. - Local utility rules and regulations. 
    Rules and regulations of the utility companies serving the city relating to point of service and meter location for the kind and character of service to be rendered as passed and approved by the city council are incorporated herein and made a part hereof as noted in Article VII. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-150. - Conformance required. 
    All electrical equipment and materials, and the installation thereof, shall be in conformity with the provisions of this chapter, the applicable statutes of the state, and any rules or regulations issued by authority thereof. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-151. - Evidence of conformity of equipment, materials. 
    Conformity of electrical equipment and materials with the current published electrical appliance and utilization equipment list, or the electrical construction materials list, or the hazardous location equipment list, of the Underwriters' Laboratories, Incorporated, or an approved agency, shall be prima facie evidence that such equipment or materials are reasonably safe to persons and property. These lists and pamphlet shall be on file in the electrical inspector's office and become a part of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-152. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person who shall violate any provision of the code adopted by the provisions of this article shall be punished by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). Each day such violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Secs. 12-153-12-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - TECHNICAL REQUIREMENTS AND STANDARDS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-11, § 1, adopted May 1, 2012, provides that the term "electrical inspector" shall be replaced with the term "code official." See also § 12-22. 

Sec. 12-161. - Central Power and Light Company Meter Installation Manual, adopted by reference. 
    The Central Power and Light Company Meter Installation Manual, later edition, shall be and the same is hereby adopted as standards for the installation of electrical equipment as the same is defined in and covered by this chapter, excepting only such electrical equipment or installation as may not be treated in such standards and for which provision is specifically made in this chapter; and the standards aforementioned are hereby made a part of this chapter as fully and to the same extent as though the text thereof were copied in full, herein. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-162. - Concealed wiring. 
    No so-called "concealed wiring" for which a permit is issued or required shall be lathed over or in any manner concealed from view until it shall have been inspected and approved by the electrical inspector. All electrical wiring shall be complete before the same shall be permitted to be concealed from view; and all electrical provisions and fittings such as cabinets, cut-outs, flush switches, etc., shall be permanently installed prior to final inspection and approval by the electrical inspector; with the exception of lighting fixtures or other fixture, the addition of which requires no additional electrical equipment or alteration. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-163. - Wiring to meet standards of National Electrical Code. 
    All electrical wiring installed within the city for any purpose whatsoever, and as provided in the sections hereinafter following, in all instances shall be installed as prescribed by the National Electrical Code as adopted in section 12-147: 
(1)  All electrical wiring in any and all buildings of any description whatsoever, situated within any fire zone in the city shall be encased in approved conduit. All outside electrical wiring (such as wiring which is not enclosed in wall or ceiling), and all electrical wiring which is embedded in concrete, shall be encased in approved rigid conduit. Thin-wall conduit may be employed in installing all other electrical wiring, provided that watertight connectors are used. The use of any machine or other device which makes an indentation in the conduit is hereby expressly prohibited. 
(2)  All use of flexible metal conduit, as prescribed in Article 350 of the National Electrical Code, latest edition, shall be limited to a maximum of six (6) feet in length and to a minimum of one-half (1/2) inch in diameter. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-164. - Prohibited wiring. 
    No person shall install, or be in any manner responsible for the installation of, any of the following prohibited equipment within the territorial limits of the city: 
(1)  "BX" or "Knob and Tube" electrical installation; 
(2)  Basement light without wall switch; 
(3)  Aluminum conductors. Any existing structure which includes this type of material and is in the process of being rehabilitated shall have this material removed and shall conform to existing codes. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000; Ord. No. 04-36, § 8, 10-18-2004) 
Sec. 12-165. - Grounding required; number of outlets restricted. 
    All cabinets and conduit installations shall be grounded in any approved manner; and the number of outlets installed on one (1) circuit in a residence at any one (1) time shall not exceed the number of eight (8). The number of outlets installed on one (1) circuit in a business establishment, school, church, hotel, or hospital shall not exceed the number of six (6). 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 12-166. - Miscellaneous requirements. 
(a)  No. 12 electrical wire shall constitute the minimum requirement for residence circuits, with the sole exception of switch legs which may consist of No. 14 wire. 
(b)  Each main line disconnect shall be installed adjacent to meter and shall be located outside of building, unless otherwise authorized by the electrical inspector in writing. 
(c)  Approved SE cable shall be permissible for use in connection with electric stoves in residences. 
(d)  Each electric water heater shall be wired in rigid metallic conduit or electrical metallic tubing with proper fittings. 
(e)  Each switch and each receptacle shall be of approved T-rating. 
(f)  Each service supplying in excess of two (2) circuits shall be of three (3) wire type. 
(g)  No public utility serving the city shall energize line until written approval of the electrical inspector shall first have been secured. 
(h)  All wire from entrance switch to panel box shall be of at least No. 8, or larger; and such wire may be SE cable for residence and duplex dwellings. 
(i)  All service wires from point of entrance of building to service switch and meter connection shall conform with the requirements of the Central Power and Light Company Meter Installation Manual. 
(j)  One hundred fifteen-volt single phase motorized equipment designed for general use shall be equipped with motors having a rating capacity of less than one-half (1/2) horsepower. 
(k)  Any person making use of any manner of electrical equipment within the territorial limits of the city which equipment has electrical characteristics such that the connection thereof with, and the use thereby of, electrical current causes or is likely to cause substantial fluctuation or fluctuations of electrical voltage and thereby effects interference with, or is likely to effect interference with, electrical service to another, shall provide at private expense suitable and effective apparatus to prevent such current fluctuation and such interference. 
(l)  Branch circuits supplying convenience outlets in the kitchen, pantry, dining room and breakfast room, as pertains to residences and other dwelling occupancies, shall not supply other outlets. Such branch circuits shall be supplied with conductors not smaller than No. 12. Laundry convenience outlets shall be on separate circuits. 
(m)  All joints of electrical equipment shall be soldered or shall be of approved mechanical connectors, and shall be taped on "rough-in-jobs." Fixture lead shall be soldered or fixture connectors of approved type shall be employed in lieu of fixture lead. All such connections, joints and fixtures shall be made in approved enclosures. 
(n)  All unused holes or openings in cabinet boxes and in outlet boxes shall be effectively plugged when not in use, to render such boxes as nearly dust-tight as possible. 
(o)  All wires and attachments in each electrical installation shall be of sufficient capacity to maintain service with the full connected load in conformity with the requirements of this chapter. 
(p)  In instances of installation of electrical equipment or service used or intended to be used to control more than one (1) apartment dwelling, consumer or installation, the main cabinet and cut-offs shall be accessible to each such dwelling, consumer or installation, at all times. 
(q)  All motors or one and one-half (11/2) horsepower or greater shall be equipped with approved motor starting devices. 
(r)  Drop cords shall not be installed at any time. 
(s)  Each electrical circuit shall be protected by a separate fuse or an approved multibreaker in the hot leg of the circuit. 
(t)  Multibreaker or fusestat shall be used in lieu of plug type fuse, in accordance with the wire size as listed in the National Electrical Code, latest edition. 
(Ord. No. 00-27, 9-5-2000) 
Chapter 13 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic regulations specifically applicable to fire trucks and control of traffic at fires, §§ 26-6, 26-19, 26-51, 26-56, and 26-57; fireworks not to be exploded in city, § 19-6. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 13-1. - False alarms, prohibited. 
    No person shall knowingly place a false fire alarm, in any manner whatsoever, or cause or attempt to cause the fire apparatus of the city to respond to any false alarm of fire within the city. Any such action shall constitute a misdemeanor, and upon conviction, punishment shall be levied in accordance with section 1-5 of this Code. 
    If the city is required to respond to any false fire alarm, at the same property, five (5) times or more within a thirty-day period, the owner of said property will be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined an amount not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. of 10-11-1927; Ord. No. 2011-01, § 1, 1-4-2011) 
Sec. 13-2. - Arson reward-Authorized. 
    There is hereby fixed and authorized payment of the cash amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for the arrest and conviction of any person or persons found guilty of committing the crime of arson, as such offense is defined by the Texas Penal Code, at any place within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 64-24, § 1, 12-15-1964; Ord. No. 2011-01, § 2, 1-4-2011) 
Sec. 13-3. - Same-Posting. 
(a)  Notice of the arson reward shall be posted on eight inch by twelve inch (8? × 12?) placards, mounted in wooden frames and protected by glass. The lettering shall be printed in clear and legible print and shall state: 
ARSON REWARD 
    The City of Eagle Pass, Texas, hereby offers a reward of TWO HUNDRED AND FIFTY DOLLARS ($250.00) for the arrest and conviction of any person or persons found guilty of committing the crime of ARSON within the corporate limits of said City of Eagle Pass, Texas. This reward is a standing offer, and shall be paid out of the contingency fund of the City of Eagle Pass, Texas. 
THE CITY OF EAGLE PASS, TEXAS 
(b)  One (1) placard shall be placed for conspicuous display inside of at least six (6) of the distinct public buildings, within the city, as follows: 
Public library; 
Waterworks system; 
School district tax office; 
City hall; 
Maverick County Courthouse; 
U.S. Post Office; 
Water Control and Improvement District No. One. 
(Ord. No. 64-24, §§ 2, 3, 12-15-1964) 
Secs. 13-4-13-13. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RESERVED[2] 

Footnotes:
