If the proposed plan is the same as the previous year, the prevention measures shall be continued until and unless the city indicates that a measure(s) needs to be modified. Unless otherwise agreed, any modifications to the plan imposed by the city notifies the owner of the needed modifications. 
(Ord. No. 98-32, § 6, 7-28-98) 
Sec. 19-91. - Penalties for failing to submit a prevention plan or evaluation report or to implement prevention measures. 
    Any owner that fails to submit a plan, implement the proposed plan measures, or implement any required modifications to the plan by the city within the time frames specified in this chapter shall be required to place disabling devices on all carts owned/leased/used by the business to prevent removal of carts from the business premises and parking lots. Any owner that fails to submit an evaluation report as outlined in section 19-90 by July 1st of each year or fails to place a disabling device on all carts, if applicable, shall be subject to an initial five hundred dollar ($500.00) civil penalty, plus an additional penalty of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each day of non-compliance. 
(Ord. No. 98-32, § 7, 7-28-98) 
Sec. 19-92. - Notification for retrieval of abandoned carts. 
    The city shall notify the owner of any abandoned carts owned or used by the business establishment that have been located within the city. The owner shall have three (3) days from the date the notification is given, to retrieve the carts from the city. 
(Ord. No. 98-32, § 8, 7-28-98) 
Sec. 19-93. - Administrative costs and fines. 
    Any owner that fails to retrieve its abandoned cart(s) within three (3) days after receiving the notice by the city, as referenced immediately above, shall pay the city's administrative costs for retrieving the cart(s) and providing the notification to the owner. Any owner who fails to retrieve abandoned carts in accordance with this chapter in excess of three times during a specified six-month period, shall be subject to a civil penalty for each occurrence. An occurrence includes all carts owned by the owner that are impounded by the city in a one-day period. 
(Ord. No. 98-32, § 9, 7-28-98) 
Sec. 19-94. - Disposition of carts after sixty days. 
    Any cart not reclaimed from the city within sixty (60) days after notification to the owner shall be sold or otherwise disposed of by the city. 
(Ord. No. 98-32, § 10, 7-28-98) 
Secs. 19-95-19-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - FLEA MARKETS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2013-14, § 1, adopted Aug. 6, 2013, repealed Art. VII and enacted a new article as set out herein. The former Art. VII, §§ 19-111-19-123, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 98-41, § 1, adopted Nov. 10, 1998. 

Sec. 19-111. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Certificate of occupancy. The term shall mean a written finding issued by the planning department stating that a building, premises or portion thereof and the proposed use of the building, premises, or portion thereof complies with the city's Code of Ordinances, including but not limited to the city's building and zoning regulations. The process for the issuance of a certificate shall be as set forth in Section 18, Appendix A, of City of Eagle Pass Code of Ordinances. 
    Flea market. The term shall mean any establishment which for a fee or remuneration of any kind permits two (2) or more persons to display for sale items including, but not limited to, wearing apparel, watches, jewelry, luggage, musical instruments, furniture, household appliances, automobile parts and accessories, hand tools, mechanical equipment, garden tools, hobby items, water heaters, pipes, electrical fittings, plumbing fittings, radios, television sets, bicycles, personal property, mobile food vendor carts operated in conformance with state, county, and city health and safety codes, and any and all kinds of used goods, wares and merchandise. A "flea market" shall not be considered a "second hand store" or "used clothes warehouse" as defined in Article IV of Chapter 20, as a flea market is not generally operated within the confines of a building. 
    Flea market operator license. The term shall mean the written approval by the city to conduct a flea market business pursuant to this article. A license shall not be issued unless accompanied by a certificate of occupancy. 
    Hard surface. The term shall mean a method of surfacing an access aisle within a flea market that is stable, firm, slip-resistant, and capable of being traversed in by a member of the disabled community, including walking or as facilitated through the use of a wheel chair, walker, or similar mobility assistance device in conformance with the provisions of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). A stable surface is one that remains unchanged by contaminants or applied force so that, when the contaminant or force is removed, the surface returns to its original condition. A firm surface resists deformation by either indentations or particles moving on its surface. A slip-resistant surface provides sufficient frictional counter force to the forces exerted in traversing the aisle to permit safe ambulation or movement. 
    Operation. The term shall mean that period time during which sales activities are conducted. 
    Significant life, health, or safety issue. The term shall mean a circumstance which may result in permanent physical impairment, through injury or death. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 1, 8-6-2013) 
Sec. 19-112. - License required. 
    No flea market shall be operated within the city without first having obtained a flea market operator license and a certificate of occupancy, the license shall be procured by complying with the following provisions: 
(a)  Application. A flea market operator shall submit an application for a license addressed to the planning department which shall contain the name, address and phone number of each owner and operator. In the case of a partnership, limited liability company (LLC), corporation or other such firm, the application shall list the names, phone numbers, and addresses of each individual member, partner, or shareholder of the entity. The application shall also contain a construction and development plan as described in section 19-122. 
(b)  Application to contain provision relative to compliance with ordinances. Such application shall contain the following words: 
"The license hereby applied for shall be subject to all provisions, ordinances and regulations of the city, including but not limited to, specific regulations related to flea market operators." 
(c)  License fees. The annual license fee for licenses under this section shall be one hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00), paid in advance of the year for which the permit is being sought. 
(d)  Application to be signed and sworn to. Such application shall be signed and sworn to by each owner and operator applying therefor before some officer authorized by law to administer oaths. 
(e)  Issuance of license. Each application shall be presented to the planning department. The department shall issue a license to the applicant upon a finding of (1) a valid certificate of occupancy, (2) compliance with the approved construction and development plan for the market, and (3) compliance by the applicant with the terms of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 1, 8-6-2013) 
Sec. 19-113. - License to be available for inspection. 
    Every flea market operator while engaged in the pursuit of their business shall have posted, in a conspicuous place in public view and available for inspection at all times, their license and certificate of occupancy to be engaged in such business. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 1, 8-6-2013) 
Sec. 19-114. - Limitations to license. 
    A license issued under this article shall not entitle the holder thereof to engage in the sale of used merchandise, but shall only authorize the holder to operate a flea market. However, this does not foreclose the flea market operator from obtaining the proper license to engage in selling used merchandise within the flea market. The license and certificate of occupancy is not transferrable or assignable. A new license and certificate shall be required if there is a change in business ownership or property ownership, a change in operators, or a revision of the construction and development plan. A license issued under this article shall expire one (1) year from the date of issuance. An application for renewal shall be submitted to the planning department at least thirty (30) days before the expiration date, and when made less than thirty (30) days before the expiration date, the expiration date of the license and certificate will not be affected by the pendency of the application. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 1, 8-6-2013) 
Sec. 19-115. - Copy of regulations to be furnished to every person who is allowed to display merchandise for sale. 
    Every flea market operator shall furnish a copy of the regulations contained within this article to every person who is allowed to display merchandise for sale within such flea market. The planning department shall revoke the flea market operator license if the operator fails to comply with this provision. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 1, 8-6-2013) 
Sec. 19-116. - Merchandise subject to inspection. 
    All merchandise on the premises of a flea market shall be subject to inspection at all times by the police department, the public works department, the fire department, and the planning department. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 1, 8-6-2013) 
Sec. 19-117. - Prohibited merchandise. 
(a)  No merchandise shall be displayed for sale at any flea market if the manufacturer's seal, identification number or brand has been removed or obliterated. 
(b)  The sale, display or distribution of merchandise bearing counterfeit trademarks or that infringes on copyrighted designs or materials shall be prohibited. 
(c)  The sale of prepackaged food, including infant formula or baby food of a type intended for consumption by children younger than two (2) years of age, medical drugs as defined in Section 431.002 of the Texas Health and Safety Code, and contact lenses, including disposable contact lenses, is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 1, 8-6-2013) 
Sec. 19-118. - Hours of business regulated. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the operation of a flea market between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 1, 8-6-2013) 
Sec. 19-119. - Location of flea markets. 
    All new flea markets in the city are prohibited unless authorized by a conditional use permit in the "I" industrial district. Any lawfully licensed and established flea market existing as of January 16, 2018, may continue to operate as a nonconforming use subject to the provisions of section 10(G)(2) of Appendix A in the Code of Ordinance for the City of Eagle Pass. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 1, 8-6-2013; Ord. No. 2018-03, § 1, 1-16-2018) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-03, § 1, adopted January 16, 2018, renamed § 19-119 from "flea markets to be located in a commercial zoning district" to "location of flea markets." 
Sec. 19-120. - Operator and vendor responsibility. 
(a)  The flea market operator shall ensure that all flea markets: 
(1)  Have direct or easement access to an arterial street. 
(2)  Have adequate off-street parking that complies with Section 12.1 of the Eagle Pass Code of Ordinances Appendix A. 
(3)  Have at least one (1) sanitary facility (restrooms) each for men and women, or one (1) uni-sex. Restroom(s) construction shall comply with the provisions of the International Building Code (IBC) and the International Plumbing Code (IPC). All restroom facilities shall comply with the provisions of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). 
(4)  Have adequate on-site garbage and/or trash collection containers as set forth in Chapter 14 of the City of Eagle Pass Code of Ordinances. Any flea market operator that does not comply with the provisions of this article shall be subject to a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each violation, with a separate violation deemed committed for each and every day that the violation(s) continues to occur. 
(5)  Sales are made from designated vendor sale areas as illustrated on the approved construction and development plan for the flea market. Sale material is prohibited to be placed within or upon any pedestrian access aisle or any required fire lane so designated on the approved construction and development plan. Booth areas, pedestrian access aisles, and fire lanes are to be clearly delineated on the property through the use of a three (3) inch wide white or yellow stripe painted on the asphalt or concrete surface area of the flea market, with the location of all booth areas, pedestrian access aisles, and fire lanes placed in accordance with the approved construction and development plan. All pedestrian access aisles and fire lanes shall be asphalt surfaced or concrete surfaced. Any alternate surfacing shall be compliant with the provisions of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and shall be approved in writing by the planning department and, in the case of a fire lane, by the fire marshal. 
Any on-premises sale of food shall be subject to the health and sanitation requirements of Chapter 16 of the City of Eagle Pass Code of Ordinances. 
(6)  Have fire prevention and protection equipment on-site. The type and location of all fire prevention features, including the six-foot-wide emergency access aisle, shall be consistent with the International Fire Code (IFC), approved by the fire marshal, and illustrated on the approved construction and development plan. 
(7)  All merchandise for sale, including temporary canopies, tables, and display structures shall be removed from the flea market property at the close of business each day, unless the material is contained (a) entirely within an enclosed storage unit or building as illustrated on the approved construction and development plan, or (b) entirely within a currently licensed trailer or licensed vehicle. The outdoor storage of merchandise is prohibited. 
A permanent canopy structure shall be permitted, provided that (a) a building permit is obtained for the structure, (b) the structure complies with the floodplain management standards set forth in Chapter 131/2 of the City of Eagle Pass Code of Ordinances, if located in a floodplain; and (c) the structure is designed in conformance with city design standards as approved by the planning department. 
(b)  Each flea market vendor shall: 
(1)  Recycle cardboard. 
(2)  Have a copy of the regulations contained within this article in their designated booth area. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 1, 8-6-2013) 
Sec. 19-121. - Construction and development plan required. 
    All flea markets in the city shall submit a construction and development plan with their flea market operator permit application that is drawn to scale and which details (1) the zoning district, (2) the sales area and booth arrangement, (3) any off-street parking area, (4) fire prevention and protection equipment, (5) fire lanes, (6) sanitary facilities, (7) pedestrian access aisles that are a minimum of six (6) feet in width, and (8) garbage and/or trash collection containers. A construction and development plan shall be submitted to the planning department with each and every annual flea market operator application, or any time there is a change in operator business ownership or property ownership, or any time there is a change of the approved construction and development plan. The planning department shall approve a proposed construction and development plan if it complies with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 1, 8-6-2013) 
Sec. 19-122. - Denial, suspension, revocation, and renewal of license. 
(a)  If, after the flea market license provided for in this article has been issued, the planning department finds that the license was obtained by false representation in the application, such license may be revoked and or not renewed by the planning department. 
(b)  Such license may also be suspended, revoked, and/or not renewed if the planning department finds that the holder of the license has (1) violated any provisions of this article, or (2) been convicted of a felony or a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude. 
(c)  If, after submission of an application for a license, the planning department finds that the application does not qualify for a license or comply with the provisions of this article, then the planning department may deny the request for a license. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 1, 8-6-2013) 
Sec. 19-123. - Appeals from decisions by the planning department. 
    If the applicant for a flea market operator license under this article or the holder of such license is dissatisfied with any finding of the planning department, they shall have the right to appeal to the city council by filing a written notice, stating all the grounds for the appeal, with the planning department within ten (10) calendar days from the date of such decision by the planning department and paying an appeal processing fee of one hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00). Upon the filing of such notice of appeal, the application for the license and all documents possessed by the planning department in connection with the application, license and certificate of occupancy shall be shall be delivered to the city council. Such matter as may be in dispute shall then be heard by the city council at the next regular meeting after the filing of the appeal. The filing of the appeal shall operate as a stay or postponement of the action taken by the planning department until final adjudication of the matter, unless there is a significant life, health, or safety issue. The city council shall have the same powers and authority on such appeal as is vested in the planning department by this article. The decision of the city council is final and binding. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 1, 8-6-2013) 
Sec. 19-124. - Enforcement and penalty for violations. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the planning department, the public works department, the fire department, and the police department to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Any person or corporation who shall violate any of the provisions of this article, or fails to comply therewith or with any of the requirements thereof, or shall build or alter any building or premises in violation of any detailed application, statement, or plan submitted and approved hereunder, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be liable to a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), with each and every day such violation shall be permitted to exist constituting a separate offense. The owner or owners of any building or premises, or part thereof, where anything in violation of this article shall be placed or shall exist, and any person or corporation employed in connection therewith and who may have assisted in the commission of any such violation, shall be guilty of a separate offense and, upon conviction thereof, be fined as hereinbefore provided. 
(c)  In addition, this article may be enforced by injunctive relief, and a person or entity found to be in violation of this article may be assessed a civil penalty of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) each and every day such violation shall be permitted to exist. If an injunction is granted, the court shall award the city its attorney fees and costs incurred in obtaining the injunctive relief. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 1, 8-6-2013) 
Secs. 19-125-19-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - GARAGE SALES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- See editor's note at article VI, Shopping Carts. 

Sec. 19-131. - Definitions. 
    The following words and terms shall have the following meanings for purposes of this article: 
    Charitable organization. Any organization qualifying as a charitable nonprofit organization under section 501(c) of the Federal Income Tax Code. 
    Garage sale operator. Any person with a permit issued by the city's tax office to operate a garage sale. 
    Garage sales. All general sales, open or advertised to the public, conducted from or on a residential premises (single-family, duplexes or apartments), in any residential zone for the purpose of disposing of tangible personal property. Said sale includes situations in which more than twenty (20) specific items of tangible personal property are to be sold. 
    Person. This term includes individuals, partnerships, voluntary associations and corporations. 
    Personal property. Property which is owned, utilized, and maintained by an individual or members of his or her residence and acquired in the normal course of living in or maintaining a residence. Merchandise purchased for resale at a garage sale or obtained by consignment for sale at a garage sale is prohibited. 
    Residence. Any single-family structure or multi-family complex whether owned, rented or leased. 
(Ord. No. 98-40, § 1, 11-10-98; Ord. No. 2016-29, § 14, 9-20-2016) 
Sec. 19-132. - Signage. 
(a)  Signs advertising garage sales shall not exceed four (4) feet square each in surface area and no more than four (4) signs may be posted for any one (1) garage sale. 
(b)  Garage sale signs must be temporary signs. No signs may be exhibited more than two (2) days prior to the sale, and all signs must be removed at the expiration of the garage sale permit. The person or persons exercising ownership or leasehold rights over property on which a garage sale is held or advertised to be held shall be presumed to have placed and exhibited the sign advertising the garage sale which identifies the person's address or location at which the garage sale is to be held. This presumption may be rebutted by evidence to the contrary. 
(c)  Signs must be staked on the garage sale operator's private property and cannot be attached to utility poles, streetlight standards or other public facilities. 
(d)  Garage sale signs may be placed on private property other than that of the garage sale operator, provided that the operator has obtained the consent of the property owner. 
(Ord. No. 98-40, § 1, 11-10-98; Ord. No. 2016-29, § 15, 9-20-2016) 
Sec. 19-133. - No food sales. 
    Sales of food items are prohibited at garage sales. 
(Ord. No. 98-40, § 1, 11-10-98) 
Sec. 19-134. - Garage sale permit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or participate in the operation of a garage sale within the city limits of the city, unless the person had first obtained a garage sale permit from the city's tax office. Each garage sale shall not exceed two (2) consecutive days. An applicant having a valid permit may operate a garage sale between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., Central Standard Time. 
(Ord. No. 98-40, § 1, 11-10-98; Ord. No. 2016-29, § 16, 9-20-2016) 
Sec. 19-135. - Maximum number of garage sales. 
(a)  The city's tax office shall issue one (1) permit for each garage sale. Each residence is allowed four (4) garage sales per calendar year per location. 
(b)  There is a five dollar ($5.00) permit processing fee non-refundable/non-transferable for all garage sales permits which shall be paid at the city's tax office. The applicant shall pay this fee prior to the issuance of a garage sale permit. 
(Ord. No. 98-40, § 1, 11-10-98; Ord. No. 2016-29, § 17, 9-20-2016) 
Sec. 19-136. - Permit nontransferable. 
    No permit covered by this article shall be transferable, nor shall a permit holder allow his name to be used by any other party for the purposes of operating a garage sale. 
(Ord. No. 98-40, § 1, 11-10-98) 
Sec. 19-137. - Permits issued in violation of this article. 
    Any permit issued in violation of any provision of this article shall be absolutely void and no rights whatsoever shall accrue. 
(Ord. No. 98-40, § 1, 11-10-98) 
Sec. 19-138. - Issuance for a permit. 
(a)  A permit for a garage sale operator's shall be obtained at the city's tax office. 
(b)  The permit will contain all information necessary to fully advise the city's tax office of the date(s), location (street address), hours of operation of the garage sale and any other information that may be reasonably required. 
(c)  Only the owner or lessee of the residential property upon which the garage sale is being conducted may obtain such permit. 
(d)  Before such permit shall be issued, the applicant must provide proof of address (driver's license, utility bills or other identification) and any other pertinent information as may be reasonably required by the city's tax office. Upon verification and compliance with provisions of this article and payment of the proper a five dollar ($5.00) permit processing fee, the applicant will be issued a permit for a garage sale by the city's tax office. 
(e)  By making a permit for such garage sale permit, and accepting to conducting a garage sale, the owner or lessee of the property to whom such permit is granted authorizes any code enforcement officer of the city to enter upon the property for the purpose of determining that such sale is being conducted in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 98-40, § 1, 11-10-98; Ord. No. 2016-29, § 21, 9-20-2016) 
Sec. 19-139. - Permit number and garage sale information. 
(a)  Each permit issued shall bear the street address of the residence where the sale will be located, the date(s) and hours when the garage sale will be held and any other information deemed necessary by the city's tax office. 
(b)  The permit must be clearly displayed and visible at the garage sale. 
(Ord. No. 98-40, § 1, 11-10-98; Ord. No. 2016-29, § 19, 9-20-2016) 
Sec. 19-140. - Removal of signs advertising garage sales. 
    A garage sale operator shall remove any advertising sign upon expiration of the garage sale permit. Violators of this section are subject to a fine not to exceed fifty dollars ($50.00) for each day past the deadline for removing signs. 
(Ord. No. 98-40, § 1, 11-10-98) 
Sec. 19-141. - Display of sale items. 
    Personal property shall be exhibited or displayed on the private property where the residence is located. Personal property cannot be placed in the public right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 98-40, § 1, 11-10-98) 
Sec. 19-142. - Exception for churches, charitable and nonprofit organizations. 
    Any church or charitable organization may hold a maximum of twelve (12) garage sales per year, provided that: 
(1)  The church or organization does not hold more than one (1) garage sale per month; 
(2)  The sale must be conducted on the church or organization property; and 
(3)  A member of the church or organization, authorized to represent it, must register with the city's tax office. No fee will be charged for registration. 
(Ord. No. 98-40, § 1, 11-10-98; Ord. No. 2016-29, § 19, 9-20-2016) 
Sec. 19-143. - Cancellation or postponement of garage sale. 
    The cancellation or postponement of a garage sale authorized pursuant to this article shall be permitted, provided that the applicant contacts the tax office twenty four (24) hours prior to the scheduled start of the operation and notifies the tax office that the event is being cancelled or postponed. The tax office shall then process a credit for the event to insure that the permit holder remains authorized to conduct the maximum number of garage sales as set forth in section 19-135. 
(Ord. No. 2016-29, § 20, 9-20-2016) 
Sec. 19-144. - Denial, suspension, revocation, and renewal of permit. 
    If, after the garage sale permit provided for in this article has been issued, the tax office finds that the permit was obtained by false representation, such permit may be revoked and or not renewed by the tax office. Such permit may also be suspended, revoked, and/or not renewed if the tax office finds that the holder of the permit has violated any provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2016-29, § 20, 9-20-2016) 
Sec. 19-145. - Enforcement and penalty for violations 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the public works department to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Any person or corporation who shall violate any of the provisions of this article, or fails to comply therewith or with any of the requirements thereof, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be liable to a fine of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00), with each and every day such violation shall be permitted to exist constituting a separate offense. The owner or owners of any building or premises, or part thereof, where anything in violation of this article shall be placed or shall exist, and any person or corporation employed in connection therewith and who may have assisted in the commission of any such violation, shall be guilty of a separate offense and, upon conviction thereof, be fined as hereinbefore provided. 
(Ord. No. 2016-29, § 20, 9-20-2016)

(Ord. No. 2016-29, § 22, 9-20-2016) 
Chapter 19.5 - OIL AND GAS WELLS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, adopted March 18, 2014, repealed Ch. 191/2 and enacted a new Ch. 19.5 as set out herein. The former Ch. 191/2, §§ 191/2-1-191/2-7, 191/2-18-191/2-22, 191/2-33-191/2-41, 191/2-52-191/2-67, 191/2-78-191/2-86, 191/2-98-191/2-121, 191/2-132-191/2-135, and 191/2-146-191/2-150, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 80-03, §§ 1-9, adopted April 4, 1980. See the Code Comparative Table for further information. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 19.5-1. - Statement of purpose; scope; repeal. 
(a)  Purpose. The city council of the City of Eagle Pass, Texas, finds that there have been or may soon be drilling and production operations for oil and gas within the corporate limits of the city, and that there is a likelihood of drilling and production operations and other operations incident to exploration, drilling and production, and incident to the existence of such operations, which should be regulated because of the hazards created by such operations, as well as the menace of unsanitary conditions, noise and the possibility of injury to persons and property and threats to the health, safety and welfare of the public in general, for which the police power of the state, which is delegated to this city, is to be and is hereby invoked, in aid of the enforcement of this chapter. 
(b)  Scope. This chapter shall govern the exploration, drilling and production of hydrocarbons and matters incident thereto, in all areas of the city. This chapter shall not apply to any part of the Rio Grande River, which is a navigable water. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-2. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the scope and meaning herein ascribed to them: 
(1)  API. The letters "API" shall mean the American Petroleum Institute. 
(2)  Applicant. The term "applicant" means any person who applies for a permit under the provisions of this chapter. 
(3)  Battery site. The term "battery site" shall mean an area, designated during the drilling of the first well in a drilling block, which shall not exceed five (5) acres in size and is to be used for the production facilities of the entire drilling block. 
(4)  City officials. The term "city officials" shall mean the mayor, city manager, city council, council, and city secretary of the City of Eagle Pass, Texas, unless otherwise expressly indicated. 
(5)  Cluster area. The term "cluster area" shall have the meaning specified in article III, Well Locations. 
(6)  Directional well. The term "directional well" means a well drilled from the surface to the bottom thereof with some portion of the hole intended to have a deviation of more than five (5) degrees from vertical. 
(7)  Drilling block. The term "drilling block" shall mean those blocks of approximately forty (40) acres identified on Exhibit A* and referred to in section 19.5-18. 
(8)  Drilling operation. The term "drilling operation" means the making of a hole in the earth for the purpose of discovery, exploration or production of oil, gas or minerals. A hydraulic fracturing process shall also be considered a drilling operation for purposes of this chapter. 
(9)  Effective date. The term "effective date" shall mean the date of the final passage of this chapter by the city council. 
(10)  Exempt acreage. Same as defined in section 19.5-20. 
(11)  Existing well. The term "existing well" means a cased well, or a well in the process of being drilled under a lawful permit on the effective date of this chapter, except as used in section 19.5-65 concerning future annexation, capable of being used in oil or gas producing operations, which is not required by this chapter to be plugged, with the exception of the wells described in paragraphs (b), (c) and (d) of section 19.5-86; provided however that any existing well which is subsequently required to be plugged shall not thereafter be considered an existing well. 
(12)  Hydraulic fracturing. The term "hydraulic fracturing," also commonly referred to as "fracking," is the procedure of creating fractures in rocks and rock formations by injecting a mixture of sand and water into the cracks to force the underground to open further. The larger fissures allow more oil and gas to flow out of the formation and into the well bore, from where it can be extracted. 
(13)  Irregular location. The term "irregular location" is the surface location of any well that is not a regular location. 
(14)  Non-producing areas. The term "non-producing areas" shall mean all drilling blocks on which there are no existing wells and which are not exempt from the unitization and well density provisions hereof, as set forth in section 19.5-20. 
(15)  Operator. The term "operator" shall include every person, and the agents, servants and employees of such person, engaged in operations for the drilling, reworking, re-drilling, well servicing or plugging and abandonment of any well subject to this chapter and the production or transportation of any product therefrom. 
(16)  Permit. The term "permit" means a permit granted pursuant to this chapter. 
(17)  Permittee. The term "permittee" is any person holding a permit granted under this chapter. 
(18)  Person. The term "person" shall include any natural person, persons or group of persons, whether acting individually, in concert, or in any representative capacity, and any partnership, private or public corporation, trust, estate, agency, trustee, executor, administrator, agent or legal entity. 
(19)  Planning department. "Planning department" shall mean the department of city government responsible for the administration of this chapter. 
(20)  Pooled unit. "Pooled unit" shall mean the assemblage of various tracts of land sufficient for the issuance of a permit to drill a well in accordance with the applicable spacing rules of this chapter. 
(21)  Production unit. The term "production unit" shall mean those areas comprising one (1) or more drilling blocks and/or parts of drilling blocks which are unitized after the effective date hereof. 
(22)  Railroad commission. The term "railroad commission" (RRC), as used in this chapter, shall mean the Railroad Commission of Texas. 
(23)  Recompletion operations. The term "recompletion operation" shall mean any operation other than a drilling operation, on an existing well, for which a Form 1 is required by the RRC. 
(24)  Regular location. The term "regular location" is the surface location of any well for which no variance is required by this chapter. 
(25)  Relief well. The term "relief well" means a well drilled or adapted under emergency circumstances to correct or safeguard against unexpected and inherently hazardous conditions. 
(26)  Straight well. The term "straight well" means a well drilled from the surface to the bottom thereof with no portion of the hole intended to have a deviation of more than five (5) degrees from vertical. 
(27)  Tight well. The term "tight well" shall mean a well for which information or data is unavailable based upon the operator's discretion. 
(28)  Unitize. The term "unitize" means the grouping of mineral interests in a given surface unit for the purpose of producing hydrocarbons as a unit. 
(29)  Well. The term "well" means any hole, excavation or bore downward from the surface, intended to extend two hundred (200) feet or more into the subsurface, made by any means or manner, for the purpose of exploring for, discovering, producing, or injecting hydrocarbons, water or other mineral, and which has not been officially plugged and abandoned. 
(30)  Well service operations. The term "well service operations" shall mean operations on a well, other than drilling operations or recompletion operations. 
    All words herein having accepted meanings in the oil and gas industry shall have the same meaning in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
* Exhibit A has not been included herein but is on file with city. 
Sec. 19.5-3. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Administrative enforcement and supervision. Administrative enforcement of the terms of this chapter shall be by the planning department. It shall be the duty of the department to enforce the provisions of this chapter and, to that end, the department is hereby vested with police authority. 
(b)  Institution of court action. In addition to any other penalty provided by this article, the council may direct the city attorney to initiate an action in any court having competent jurisdiction to enjoin any violations of the provisions of this chapter or for an injunction to compel compliance with any provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-4. - Public excluded from facilities; planning department right to entry. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, unless authorized by the operator, to enter a fenced area around any well or production facility. It shall be unlawful for any person, unless authorized by the operator, to touch any well or production equipment. Notwithstanding any other provisions hereof, the planning department shall have the right to enter the area of any drill site or battery site at any time. In the event any fence surrounding any well or production facility shall be kept locked, upon request of the department, the key or the combination shall be furnished to the department for use in access to said premises. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-5. - Violation of this chapter; constitutionality of provisions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, either by himself or agent, to knowingly perform any act prohibited by the terms of this chapter or in any way violate the provisions thereof. A separate violation is committed each day in which a violation occurs. Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined an amount not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(b)  Prosecution for a violation under subsection (a) does not prevent the use of other enforcement remedies applicable to the person charged with or the conduct involved in the violation. 
(c)  If any section, subsection, paragraph, clause, phrase, word, provision, or portion of this chapter shall be held to be unconstitutional or invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, such holding or decision shall not affect or impair the validity of this chapter as a whole or any part thereof, other than the portion so held to be invalid. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-6. - Jurisdiction. 
    This chapter shall be enforced within the city limits of the City of Eagle Pass, Texas and within its extraterritorial jurisdiction granted the city pursuant to Texas Local Government Code Chapter 212. In the event that a drilling site is located within the boundary of an area subject to the authority of the International Boundary Water Commission (IBWC), a letter from the IBWC shall be obtained authorizing the site for extraction and the letter shall be included in the application for a drilling permit pursuant to article IV of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Secs. 19.5-7-19.5-17. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DRILLING BLOCKS AND PRODUCTION UNITS 

Sec. 19.5-18. - Drilling blocks. 
(a)  In order that the purpose and intent of this chapter, as stated in section 19.5-1, shall be carried out and future drilling for oil and gas within the city may proceed in an orderly manner, and for convenience and clarity in identifying the location of approved or proposed drilling locations, the area of the city to which this chapter applies (with the exceptions noted in section 19.5-20) has been divided into drilling blocks, each containing approximately forty (40) acres. Each block is shown and identified on the map attached hereto as Exhibit A. 
(b)  All mineral interests in each drilling block shall be utilized as herein provided with the exceptions noted in section 19.5-20. No application to drill on any drilling block where all or part is required to be unitized will be approved unless the applicant shows that he owns or controls by voluntary agreement more than fifty-one (51) percent of the total operating rights in the drilling block, or that portion of the block left after deducting exempt acreage, to be unitized. No more than one (1) completion shall be made in any reservoir on any drilling block except under state-owned leases until special field rules have been adopted by the RRC for the reservoir. The final well density within each drilling block will be no greater than that prescribed by the railroad commission in special field rules which may be adopted for the field. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Note- See the note following § 19.5-2. 
Sec. 19.5-19. - Survey description of drilling blocks. 
    Each applicant is required by article IV of this chapter to file an application with the planning department to drill which shall include a metes-and-bounds description of the drilling block proposed to be covered by the permit. Such metes-and-bounds description shall be prepared by a surveyor licensed by the State of Texas, and shall conform to the extent reasonably possible to the outlines of drilling blocks shown on Exhibit A. No such metes-and-bounds description shall be approved by the department unless its outside boundaries substantially conform to the general pattern shown on Exhibit A. When so approved, such description shall become the official legal description of the drilling block therein for all purposes hereunder. The department shall take into account the metes-and-bounds description of all previously approved drilling blocks in determining the propriety of the description furnished in connection with any permit application in order to obtain ultimate conformity to the pattern shown on Exhibit A. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Note- See the note following § 19.5-2. 
Sec. 19.5-20. - Exemptions to unitization and well density requirements. 
    Exemptions to unitization and well density requirements shall be subject to the following criteria: 
(1)  Each drilling block, as to all depths and all minerals hereunder, is exempt from the well density and unitization provisions of this chapter when an existing well, as defined in section 19.5-2(11) hereof, is situated thereon and such unitization and density exemption shall continue so long as said existing well is not required to be plugged and thereafter shall continue to be exempt if the conditions in subsection (4) of this section are met. 
(2)  All or such portion of a drilling block which is included in a pooled unit with an existing well situated on said unit is exempt and shall continue exempt after such well is required to be plugged, if the conditions of subsection (4) of this section are met. 
(3)  All or such portion of a drilling block which is included in a pooled unit with an existing well situated on such unit or which is covered by an oil and gas lease or leases and allocated to an existing well in which common ownership exists between said well and said lease or leases is exempt from the well density and unitization provisions of this chapter and such exemption shall continue after the existing well is required to be plugged if the conditions of subsection (4) of this section are met. 
(4)  Upon a cessation of production in paying quantities from any existing well (unless the well meets the conditions described in paragraph (e) in section 19.5-86), and if additional drilling or reworking operations are commenced on such well or a replacement well is commenced within ninety (90) calendar days and prosecuted with no cessation of more than ninety (90) consecutive days until production of oil, gas or other mineral is restored, such production shall continue as an exemption from the well density and unitization provisions of this chapter. 
(5)  Wherever, under subsection (2) of this section, a portion only of a drilling block is exempt, if the remaining portion of a drilling block is twenty (20) acres or more, it shall thereafter constitute the drilling block. If the remaining portion is less than twenty (20) acres, it also shall be exempt as part of the original drilling block and operated under the same conditions. 
(6)  All exempt activities shall be documented in writing by the planning department. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-21. - Removal of exemption. 
    When exempt acreage, which constitutes only a part of a drilling block, no longer meets any condition for exemption provided in section 19.5-20, such acreage shall become a part of the original drilling block out of which it was taken and subject to all the provisions of this chapter; provided however, that if there is then a producing well on the remaining part of said original drilling block, that acreage which was previously exempt shall become part of whatever other drilling block to which it is adjacent with which it has the longest common boundary and on which there is no producing well or existing exemption from the well density and unitization provisions of this chapter; and provided further, that if there is no such other adjacent drilling block, the acreage which has lost its exemption shall become a separately designated drilling block with the same number as the original number of the drilling block out of which it was taken but with the letter "F" following the number. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-22. - Formation of production units larger than drilling blocks. 
    It is realized that unit areas larger than a drilling block are sometimes desirable and more beneficial to effectively develop and drain a hydrocarbon reservoir. To this end it is therefore permissible for an applicant or a permittee to form unitized areas, as to specific or all horizons, larger than the drilling block in which a well has been drilled. After the effective date, the formation of a production unit which is larger than a single drilling block shall be subject to the following requirements: 
(1)  Such a production unit shall consist of an area which embraces contiguous entire drilling blocks within which the operator shall have more than fifty-one (51) percent of the operating rights in each drilling block included in such production unit. 
(2)  No such production unit will be formed in a manner that will prevent the inclusion of any adjoining drilling block with other acreage to form another production unit larger than such adjoining drilling block unless the operator proposing to form the original production unit presents evidence reasonably acceptable to the planning department that they have given an opportunity to the mineral interest owners in said adjoining drilling block by thirty (30) calendar days written notice, delivered to or mailed by certified mail to their last known address, offering the option to unitize their interests with the mineral interests in the production unit proposed to be formed by the operator. If the owners of more than fifty-one (51) percent of the operating rights, as operating rights are defined in section 19.5-22, article VII hereof, in said drilling block desire to join in said production unit and execute within said thirty (30) calendar day period pooling agreements on the same proportionate basis and containing terms and conditions as the pooling agreements executed by other mineral interest owners in said production unit, such adjoining drilling block shall become a part of the production unit. If fifty-one (51) percent or less of the mineral interest owners in said adjoining drilling block executes such pooling agreements within said time, the same shall not be required to be included within the production unit proposed to be formed by the operator. 
(3)  All mineral interests in each production unit, whether the production unit consists of a single drilling block or more than one (1) drilling block, shall be unitized as herein provided as to each horizon from which production is obtained. 
(4)  Production units may be formed or declared for all depths or for separate horizons. 
(5)  The planning department shall be provided a survey plat for each drilling block contained in the production unit, as well as a survey plat of the boundaries of the entire production unit. A statement as to horizons governed by the production unit and a copy of the mineral interest ownership setting out percentages of ownership for the production unit will be filed with the planning department by the time of commencement of production. 
(6)  Well density within the production unit will not exceed one (1) well per drilling block per producing horizon unless an increase in well density is permitted by the railroad commission. 
(7)  In all cases where a production unit is formed composed of acreage in more than one (1) drilling block, but the drilling permit only covers one (1) drilling block, all of the above requirements shall be met by applying for an amended drilling permit and receiving such amended permit before proceeding further with drilling or production operations. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Secs. 19.5-23-19.5-32. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WELL LOCATIONS 

Sec. 19.5-33. - Well locations-Generally. 
    All wells drilled in search of oil, gas or other minerals within the city limits shall be drilled in accordance with the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-34. - Streets, alleys and easements. 
    No well shall be drilled within any street right-of-way, alley right-of-way, or utility easement or located closer than the height of the drilling derrick plus fifty (50) feet from any street right-of-way, alley right-of-way or utility easement unless the operator applies for and obtains an exception approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-35. - Distance from residences, buildings or structures. 
    No well shall be drilled at any location which is nearer than four hundred (400) feet from any residentially-zoned lot or permanent structure intended for human occupancy. The council may grant an exception and allow the drilling of a well which does not meet the requirements of this section if the applicant furnishes to the planning department written waivers executed by all owners of such residences and such structures, which are located within four hundred (400) feet from the proposed location, whereby the owners waive objection to the location, provided that no exception shall be given if a well is proposed to be drilled at a location which is nearer than two hundred fifty (250) feet from a residentially-zoned lot. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-36. - Near schools, hospitals, etc. 
    No well shall be drilled at any location which is on or within four hundred (400) feet from any exterior boundary line or six hundred (600) feet from any building or land used by any public or parochial school, college, university, or hospital, or which is occupied by a church or a public building, or six hundred (600) feet from any building in use by a church, college, university or hospital, or which is occupied by a church or public building. The city council is specifically authorized to grant an exception and allow the drilling of a well which does not meet the requirements of this section if the applicant presents written evidence to the council that the owners or the governing body of such public or parochial school, college, university, hospital, church or public building have consented and agreed in writing to the proposed well location. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-37. - Near cemeteries, parks and historic places. 
    No well shall be drilled at any location which is on, or less than four hundred (400) feet from, the exterior boundary line of lands utilized for cemeteries, public parks, or sites listed on the state register of historic places or the federal register of historic places. 
    In the event that a drilling site is located on a property that directly abuts the boundary of a site listed on the state register or federal register of historic places, then the applicant shall obtain a written finding of no significant impact from the project to the historic site from the respective state of federal agency authorized to provide such determination and include the written finding in the drilling permit application. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-38. - Deed restriction provisions. 
    Nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed as authorizing the drilling of any well where the operator has no legal authority to do so. It is expressly provided that no well shall be drilled at any location where there are, of public record, legally enforceable deed restrictions or covenants prohibiting the drilling of such well. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-39. - Surface rights. 
    Neither this chapter nor any permit issued hereunder shall be interpreted as granting any right or license to the permittee to enter upon or use any land; nor shall it limit or prevent the free right of the owner of such land to contract for any payment of any kind for damages or for rights or privileges with respect thereto. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-40. - Cluster of producing facilities. 
(a)  Only one (1) "battery site" within each drilling block may be used. The operator of the first well drilled in each drilling block will designate a battery site, not to exceed five (5) acres, for said production facilities for that drilling block and will submit to the planning department a professional engineer's survey and written evidence of the surface owner's consent granted for using such battery site, along with the operator's written agreement to permit other operators, if they have or will have production from wells drilled in the same drilling block, to use the same facilities on a fair and equitable basis or to erect separate facilities in the same designated battery site. When a producible well is completed, which well was drilled in a drilling block where producing facilities already exist, the operator of the nearest existing battery site in such drilling block shall be required, on a fair and equitable basis, to permit the operator of the new well to either use the existing facilities or erect his own on said battery site. The council may grant exceptions to this section when it finds that the existing facilities and/or battery site is inadequate to service other production or to include other facilities, and also that the public health, safety and welfare is not endangered by creating another battery site in such drilling block. 
(b)  In the event the hydrogen sulfide concentration of a well or system exceeds the minimum standards set up under Rule 36 of the Statewide Conservation Rules, such battery site shall be located on an area situated outside the city limits and selected and equipped by the operator to be used for installing, maintaining and using facilities for collecting, separating, treating and transporting production from a well or system. In such event, the operator will comply with the general provisions contained in Statewide Rule 36 and will file with the planning department all reports and the certificate of compliance that they are required to file with the RRC. In addition, such operator shall provide the planning department with a copy of their contingency plat as defined in Statewide Rule 36 and shall post warning signs in English and in Spanish to adequately warn the general public and the operator's employees of potential danger. In addition, markers shall be installed at locations identified by the planning department and the fire department to identify the location of the line to prevent accidental rupture. Unless the operator receives an exemption from the council, they shall not be able to work over, produce, inject, gather, process, transport or store sour gas or liquid hydrocarbon when the hydrogen sulfide concentration in such system exceeds one hundred (100) parts per million (ppm) for liquids, with the concentration of hydrogen sulfide measured in the vapor released from the liquid in standard conditions. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-41. - Well location partly within drilling block. 
    A well may have a surface location in one (1) drilling block and be bottomed in a production block not directly under such drilling block, provided that the surface location meets the requirements of this chapter and the bottom hole location complies with the location requirements of the RRC. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Secs. 19.5-42-19.5-51. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DRILLING AND OPERATING PERMITS 

Sec. 19.5-52. - Permits required. 
    It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for any person, acting either for himself or as an agent, employee, independent contractor or servant of any other person, to commence to drill, to drill or to operate any well or to assist in the drilling, completing or operating of any such well for which a permit is required hereunder if a lawful permit has not been obtained. In addition to the other requirements of this article, a new permit is required to re-enter any well which has been plugged and abandoned as though the well were a new well, and it shall be unlawful for any person, acting either for themselves or as an agent, employee, independent contractor or servant of any other person, to re-enter such a well without first obtaining a permit therefor. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-53. - Application for drilling permit. 
(a)  An application for a drilling permit shall be filed in duplicate, with all exhibits attached securely thereto, in the office of the planning department for each well to be drilled. Such application shall be signed, and the accuracy of the contents thereof and exhibits thereto shall be sworn to before a notary public by the applicant, or a representative of the applicant having legal authority to enter into contracts binding upon the applicant, shall contain a sworn statement that the applicant shall comply with all requirements of this chapter and shall include, as exhibits constituting a part of the same where appropriate, the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant; and if the applicant is a corporation, the name and address of the registered agent for such corporation; and if the applicant is a partnership, the names and addresses of the general partners. 
(2)  The name, address and telephone number of a person, other than the applicant, designated as the local agent of the applicant to receive for the applicant all processes, citations, notices and demands hereunder. If appropriate, more than one (1) telephone number and e-mail address should be furnished. 
(3)  As Exhibit 1, the numerical designation of the drilling block and production block(s) covered thereby, the metes-and-bounds description as reflected by the survey description of the drilling block and production block(s) and a statement to the effect that, to the best of the knowledge and belief of the applicant, his application for permit to drill complies with all of the requirements of this chapter. 
(4)  The applicant shall file, in addition to the required metes-and-bounds description, a plat of the drilling block and production block proposed to be covered by the permit prepared and certified by a surveyor licensed by the State of Texas which shall show the proposed surface location of the well, its elevation, together with distances from said proposed surface location to the exterior boundary lines of said drilling block and production block. Said plat shall show distances from the proposed surface well location to any residence or structures intended for human occupancy which are located within four hundred (400) feet from said surface well location and shall show whether or not such well location is in compliance with sections 19.5-34 and 19.5-35 of this chapter. 
(5)  Proposed total depth of the well to be drilled. 
(6)  Proposed casing, cementing and mud program of the well. 
(7)  True copies of RRC Form One and RRC drilling permit, shall be attached as Exhibit 2 and Exhibit 3, respectively. 
(8)  A copy of the notice to the Federal Aviation Administration of intention to drill said well shall be attached as Exhibit 4, if such notice is required by such agency. 
(9)  Insurance certificate dated no more than ten (10) calendar days prior to filing the application shall be attached as Exhibit 5. This certificate shall indicate that the applicant has complied with at least the minimum insurance requirements specified in this chapter in article VI, including the naming of the city as an additional named insured, and that the insurance covers the drilling, production and operation of wells within the city limits. 
(10)  A copy of such bonds as required by this chapter shall be attached as Exhibit 6. If no bond is required by this chapter, the applicant shall attach as Exhibit 6 a statement to the effect that no bond is required with a brief statement pertaining to the reason for the exception of the bond requirement. 
(11)  In the event the location is situated within the limits of the area subject to the authority of the International Boundary Water Commission (IBWC), a letter from an officer in authority of such commission authorizing the location for the drilling of such well shall be attached as an Exhibit 7. 
(12)  The permit application shall include a statement by the applicant authorizing the city to expend such funds as may be necessary under the direction and advice of the railroad commission, under the circumstances, to regain well control in accordance with the terms and provisions of section 19.5-110 of this chapter. 
(13)  Such application shall also contain a statement in which the applicant agrees to file with the planning department the reports described in section 19.5-81 of this chapter. 
(b)  All applications for permits to drill shall be accompanied by a filing fee of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) in cash or by cashier's check made payable to the city. 
(c)  Each application shall be accompanied by a title report or similar document listing the names and last known addresses of all record owners of interests in and to oil, gas, and other minerals under the property included within the production block or unit described on Exhibit 1 and shall specify the fractional share of operating rights within such drilling, production block or unit owned or controlled by the applicant, including operating rights acquired by contract from other operating interest owners. This subsection shall not apply to applications for additional drilling permits for wells to be located in production blocks or units where such information has already been furnished. 
(d)  The applicant will agree in the application to furnish the planning department before the commencement of actual drilling operations with a sworn inventory of the drilling equipment to be utilized, which inventory shall include but not be limited to the types of pumps, engines, derrick, blowout prevention equipment and other necessary and appurtenant equipment to be used in drilling operations by the drilling contractor or the operator so as to reflect compliance with this chapter. No actual drilling operations will be commenced by an operator until they receive a permit from the planning department. The planning department shall issue the permit if the drilling equipment meets complies with the provisions of this chapter. In the event the planning department considers that such equipment is inadequate for the operations to be carried within the city limits, they shall request the operator add additional pieces of equipment or shall inform the city council that they recommend that such not be utilized, and the city council shall have the right to request from the operator that such equipment comply with the specifications set out by the planning department or, if the operator does not meet such requirements, cancel the permit. 
(e)  Such application shall be accompanied by the applicant's statement that they agree to present any evidence to the city council, in addition to the requirements of this chapter, as may be requested by the council and that, to the best of applicant's belief, the proposed drilling, completion, and production operations can be safely conducted. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-54. - Recompletion operations. 
    No application is required for recompletion operations in any well. A final report shall be filed with the planning department within thirty (30) calendar days after the recompletion of the well, and shall include a diagram of the well bore showing completion depth, pipe sizes, and a brief description of the work performed. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-55. - Well service operation. 
    No application or reports are required for well service operations, but the operations shall be conducted in compliance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-56. - Application meeting chapter requirements shall be granted by city council. 
    Upon receipt of an application for a permit to drill and operate a well, the planning department shall date and set up a file for this application and examine same for compliance with this chapter. If the application is in compliance with all requirements of the chapter, the planning department shall recommend and advise the city council to approve such request, and the city council shall, if it concurs with the planning department's recommendation, publish a notice of the intention to grant such application unless someone files a written protest in opposition to the granting of the permit within ten (10) calendar days from date of publication. 
    If the application is in compliance with all provisions of this chapter, and no written protest in opposition to the granting of the permit is filed based on one (1) or more of the grounds set forth in section 19.5-60 of this chapter, then the city council may, in accordance with this chapter and within fifteen (15) calendar days after date of publication of notice, issue a permit. 
    If a written protest in opposition to the application is filed within ten (10) calendar days from the date of publication of the notice, and the planning department determines that the protest is not well founded, they will, after three (3) calendar days notice to the protestant, recommend to the city council that they issue the permit; unless the protestant, within said three (3) calendar days, files notice of request of a hearing to the city council at the city secretary's office. 
    In the event the planning department has found cause to recommend denial of a permit, then the planning department shall, within ten (10) calendar days of the filing of said application, inform the applicant in writing of reasons for recommending such denial to the city council. In that event, the applicant may request from the planning department that such application be submitted to the city council for approval under the provisions of section 19.5-57. 
    In the event of a written protest on grounds which are subsequently found by the city council to be sufficient, followed by the denial of the permit, the planning department shall return the original copy of the application, and return one-half (1/2) of the filing fee to the applicant if no steps have been taken within thirty (30) calendar days after return of the application. In the event the applicant rectifies the reason for denial of the permit and resubmit the same to the planning department for re-submission to the city council, the return of the one-half (1/2) of the filing fee shall be forfeited. In the event that the applicant requires submission of such application to the city council, the city council shall set a date for the hearing and publish a notice as provided in section 19.5-58 and inform the applicant of the date of such hearing. Sections 19.5-59 and 19.5-60 of this chapter shall be applicable to the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-57. - Procedure where granting a permit is not recommended by the planning department. 
(a)  If the planning department does not recommend the granting of a permit to the city council and the applicant desires to present direct testimony to the city council, the applicant shall comply with subsection (b) below. 
(b)  The original copy of the application, accompanied by the filing fee and a copy of the planning department's written recommendation of denial, shall be forwarded to the city secretary for hearing by the city council. The city secretary shall set the hearing for the next regular meeting of the city council after publication of a notice of such hearing as provided in section 19.5-58 below; however, where it is shown by the application, without contradiction by the planning department, that all of the land within four hundred (400) feet of the proposed surface drilling site is under lease to the applicant and no residence, building or other permanent structure intended for human occupancy is within four hundred (400) feet of the proposed drilling surface site, no notice shall be necessary under this or the preceding section, and a hearing may be held by the city council at any time after filing of the application with the city secretary. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-58. - Hearing notice; form; proof of publication; notification of owners of operating rights. 
(a)  Notice of the filing of an application and hearing to be held by the city council thereon under this article IV, and the date of the hearing thereon shall be given by the city secretary, at the applicant's expense, by publication in one (1) issue of a daily newspaper published in the city, with the notice to be published at least fifteen (15) calendar days prior to the date of the hearing. 
(b)  Such notices shall be in substantial compliance with the following form: 
"Notice is hereby given that ________________ as applicant, pursuant to the provisions of article IV of the Oil and Gas Drilling Ordinance of the City of Eagle Pass, did on the ________ day of _________, 20________, file with the city secretary an application for a permit to drill and/or operate a well upon the City of Eagle Pass Drilling Block No. ________ a general description of which is as follows:  _____
_____
_____
_____ 
Said application and a plat showing the lands comprising said drilling block and production block(s) and the exterior boundaries thereof are on file in the office of the city secretary and are at said office subject to the examination of all persons during regular office hours. A hearing upon such application will be held at the City Hall by the city council on the ________ day of _________, 20________, at ________ o'clock ________.m., and at such continued hearing or hearings, if any, as the city council may, in its discretion, designate." 
(c)  Proof of publication of such notice shall be made by the printer or publisher of the newspaper publishing the same by affidavit filed with the city secretary, and such affidavit shall be prima facie evidence of such publication. 
(d)  The applicant shall notify in writing all the owners of operating rights in the area covered by the drilling permit so requested. Such notification will be sent by certified mail at such owner's last known address. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-59. - Hearing continuance. 
    In the event a majority of the members of the city council are not present at a hearing on an application for a permit, or, at the discretion of the members of the city council, if a majority of the members thereof are present at the hearing, the hearing may be continued to a designated time and date. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-60. - Refusal of permit, generally. 
(a)  The city council shall have the power to refuse any application for a permit to drill and operate any well at any particular location within any drilling block based upon a finding regarding: 
(1)  The particular location and the character and value of the permanent improvements already erected on or approximately adjacent to the particular location in question; 
(2)  The use to which the land and surroundings are adapted for school, college, university, hospital, park or civic purpose; 
(3)  For health or safety reasons; and/or 
(4)  The drilling or operation of such well on the particular location might be injurious or a disadvantage to the city or to its inhabitants as a whole, or to a substantial member of its inhabitants or visitors as a group. 
    The council may grant a permit, as they may deem necessary, on such reasonable conditions as to protect all persons who, and property which, may be affected by the drilling and production operations. When the council refuses to issue a permit for the particular drilling location on the drilling block as applied for by the applicant, they may, in lieu thereof, designate as the drilling location a different drilling site on the drilling block or elsewhere subject to the applicant obtaining all requisite leases, contracts and surface permissions for the designated substitute drilling site. 
(b)  The city secretary shall inform the applicant and the planning department of the action of the city council within three (3) calendar days after the council has made a decision. If for any reason the permit as applied for is not granted, or if the applicant refuses the permit because of any condition imposed therein, the application and filing fee, less a service charge of one-half (1/2) of the filing fee, shall be returned to the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-61. - Transfer of permit. 
    A permit validly in force may be transferred from permittee to another operator upon approval of a written application to the city council with a transfer fee of three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) and a proper showing that such new operator has acquired, by assignment, obligations of permittee under this chapter, and has complied with the insurance, bond, and all other requirements of this chapter. Upon approval by the city council of such application, the city council shall issue a revised permit to such new operator and cancel the original permit. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-62. - Effect of drilling permit. 
    A drilling permit properly applied for and issued in accordance with this chapter is permission by the city to the operator to drill such well in accordance with application and conditions of the permit, and is also permission to produce the well and erect necessary facilities or equipment to handle its production, all in accordance with the terms and conditions of this chapter, but shall never be construed to infringe upon the rights, jurisdiction, rules and regulations of any other regulatory authority, nor upon private rights of any person affected thereby. Further, the granting of such a permit shall not excuse the permittee from the compliance in full with all other requirements of this chapter, nor from the compliance in full with any law, rule or regulation of any other regulatory authority having jurisdiction, or any rule or law applicable to such permittee or applicant pertaining to any individual person or persons, or property. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-63. - Tenure of drilling permit. 
    The term of a drilling permit shall be for a period of twelve (12) months, unless within such period operations are commenced, in which event the period shall continue as long thereafter as production is obtained in drilling, reworking, and recompletion or well service operations are conducted with no cessation of all such production and operations for more than ninety (90) consecutive days, and until the well is plugged and abandoned in accordance with this chapter and a release of the permit issued by the planning department. However, upon written request of the operator, endorsed with comment by the planning department, presented to the city council, extension of said permit period for an aggregate period of not more than six (6) months, or fraction thereof, may, in its discretion, be granted by the city council on motion if the city council finds: 
(1)  The city, by act or omission, has substantially caused the delay in meeting chapter requirements; or 
(2)  Acts of God, or conditions totally beyond the control of the operator, have caused the inability to comply. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-64. - Amendment of drilling permit. 
(a)  The holder of an unexpired and unused drilling permit may, upon application and payment of a permit of eight thousand dollars ($8,000.00) for a drilling permit, obtain an amended drilling permit from the city council for the purpose of changing the surface location from a regular or irregular location to another location. Any application for a change in surface drilling location of an irregular location will be processed in accordance with sections 19.5-57, 19.5-58, 19.5-59, and 19.5-60 of this chapter. 
(b)  Any holder of an unexpired and unused permit or the holder of a permit in the actual process of drilling may, upon good cause shown, together with such other information as requested by the city council, obtain an amended permit from the city council for the purpose of changing bottom hole location, depth or direction of the hole from the same surface location, if the council considers such amendment proper and justified. The holder of a permit in the process of conducting actual drilling operations may, upon application and the payment of an eight thousand dollar ($8,000.00) fee, obtain from the planning department an amended permit only if such request is made under emergency situations which, because of the element of time, would not be prudent to request such approval of the city council.
