The operator shall request from the planning department an amended permit, and, if the planning department considers that the same should be granted under the circumstances, they shall be granted such permit subject to the planning department making a report to the city council. Any operator, on filing for an amended permit, shall file a duplicate copy of any application made by them to the Railroad Commission of the State of Texas or any other governmental agency having jurisdiction on the drilling of such well. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-65. - Future annexation; application for registration; penalty for failure to apply. 
(a)  The owner or operator of every existing well within any territory hereafter annexed shall, within six (6) months after the effective date of annexation, be subject to an application for permit with the planning department. Such well shall be entitled an operating permit to be issued by the city council upon an application showing: 
(1)  The then condition of the well and the amount and size of pipe and casing therein, the depth from which production is being obtained and what is being produced. 
(2)  A sketch or map showing the location in relation to a permanent marker, such as in a street or road intersection, or with metes and bounds referenced to a filed plat so as to show the exact location of the surface installation at the site of such well including the drilling block number and its elevation. 
(3)  A short description of the surface installations, including tanks, pumping equipment, and compressors. 
(4)  A specification of existence of any buildings, structures or public roads to the well location within four hundred (400) feet of the location. 
(5)  An affidavit shall be attached verifying the truth of the statements contained in the application as well as showing the name of the operator and the name and addresses of the owners of the working interest. 
(6)  A certificate of insurance in accordance with the requirements of section 19.5-132 of this chapter. 
(7)  A copy of all railroad commission forms filed by such operator pertaining to such wells. 
(b)  In the event the owner or operator of an existing well does not, within six (6) months of annexation, file an application to operate such well, they shall incur a penalty of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day, and the city shall have the right to order the cessation of operations of such well until such application is filed. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-66. - Seismic surveys; application and fee; planning department to file report. 
(a)  No geophysical work employing underground explosives will be permitted anywhere at any time within the city limits. Other geophysical systems employing the "thumper," "vibroseis," and other techniques not employing explosives will be permitted upon the submission of a complete geophysical permit application and the payment of a one thousand dollar ($1,000.00) application fee. A complete application shall include the following: 
(1)  A letter of application requesting a geophysical permit. The letter shall set out when it is intended to begin the work and also the anticipated date of completion. A statement shall also be made relieving the city of any liability for damages which may result from that operation performed by the applicant. 
(2)  The letter of application shall be accompanied by proof that the applicant has complied with the insurance requirements as set out in section 19.5-132 of this chapter. 
(3)  A plat outlining the areas proposed to be covered by the survey. 
(4)  Proof that the applicant has obtained permission from the owners of the surface and subsurface to conduct such operations. 
(5)  If the applicant is acting as contractor for another party, then a letter of authorization to perform such work must accompany the application. 
(b)  When the above is properly submitted, the city council may issue a permit to the applicant to conduct such geophysical work. Before the granting of such permit, the planning department shall file a report with the city council that, in their finding, that this work will not create a public nuisance nor be contrary to the public safety. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-67. - Annual inspection fee; planning department report; exceptions to inspection fee. 
    There is hereby levied an annual per well inspection fee of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00), which shall be due and payable during the month of January of each calendar year, and a failure to pay such fee shall be cause for revocation of any permit issued under this chapter. The planning department will prepare an annual well inspection report which is to be made available to the operator prior to January 1st of each year. In the event a notice of intent to plug and abandon a well has been filed with the planning department prior to January 31st, but which abandonment may not have been completed by January 31st, payment of said two thousand five hundred dollar ($2,500.00) fee for that well shall be excused provided such well is finally plugged and abandoned in accordance with this chapter prior to March 1st of that same year. A new well on which drilling operations are in progress on the 31st day of January shall be exempt from the two thousand five hundred dollar ($2,500.00) fee for the remainder of that calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Secs. 19.5-68-19.5-77. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - RULES FOR DRILLING AND PRODUCING OPERATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 19.5-78. - Compliance with laws, rules and regulations. 
    Any violation of any valid law or any valid rule, regulation or requirement of any state or federal regulatory body having jurisdiction with reference to drilling, completing, equipping, operating, producing, maintaining or abandoning oil or gas wells or related appurtenances, equipment or facilities, or with reference to firewalls, fire protection, blowout protection or safety of persons or property shall be a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-79. - Jurisdiction of regulating authorities. 
    It is especially provided and recognized that the Texas Railroad Commission and the Texas Water Development Board and any other state or federal regulatory authority, which normally regulates the oil and gas industry has jurisdiction of the wells and operations within the city and this chapter, shall not be considered to limit such jurisdiction, rules or regulations, but shall only be considered as supplemental rules and regulations. Any operator or permittee operating or intending to operate within the jurisdictional limits of the city shall not only comply with all requirements of this chapter and any future amendments to this chapter or any special rules of the city council, but shall also comply with all rules, regulations and laws pertaining to the oil and gas operators, wells, production, etc., of the Texas Railroad Commission, the Texas Water Development Board and any other authority regulating such industry. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-80. - Exceptions. 
    An exception to any requirement of this article may be granted by the city council, upon request by operator, after the council has received a recommendation on such request made by the planning department and a public hearing is held. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-81. - Daily reports; periodic inspections; notification of planning department prior to certain operations. 
    Daily drilling reports shall be maintained on-site by the operator and provided, upon request, to the planning department. The planning department will make inspections of all wells in the process of being drilled or completed to ascertain compliance with the provisions of this chapter. Prior to the running of casing, cementing operations, installation of production equipment or perforation operations, the operator shall notify the planning department forty-eight hours (48) hours in advance of the activity so the planning department may be present to inspect the activity. The activity shall not be scheduled to be undertaken on any Saturday, Sunday, or city holiday. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-82. - Final reports; furnishing logs. 
(a)  Within thirty (30) calendar days after completion of any well, the operator shall file in the planning department a final report including the casing program utilized in the well, all cementing affidavits, all tests, a description of equipment and all necessary reports required by all governmental regulatory bodies or agencies having jurisdiction. In addition, such final reports shall specify any changes in well location, depth, and any other variation from the terms of the application. The final report shall specify the perforated interval and include information pertaining to other sands, if any. 
(b)  The planning department or the city council may request from the operator that they furnish to the planning department or the city council, copies of all logs run on such well. If such request is made by the city council and such well is not a tight well, the operator shall furnish copies of such logs to the planning department or the city council; and if it is a tight well, they shall furnish them six (6) months after the completion of such well. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-83. - Annual report. 
    Ninety (90) calendar days from the effective date, and on or before the 31st day of January of each year, beginning with January 31, 1980, every operator of a well located within the city limits as of the preceding January 1st and which has not been plugged and abandoned shall file with the planning department a report listing each and every such well by name and number and applicable paragraph of section 19.5-120 under which each exception from plugging and abandonment is claimed. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-84. - Maintenance of equipment and premises. 
(a)  The operator shall maintain all production equipment in good condition. 
(b)  All surface areas utilized by an operator for production facilities shall be kept clear of dry grass, weeds and combustible trash or other rubbish or debris that would, if allowed to accumulate, result in a fire hazard. In the event the operator does not keep the premises clean, the planning department may have it contracted and the payment of such work performed shall constitute a valid lien against the property. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-85. - Wells to be abandoned; exceptions. 
(a)  All wells within the city limits which are not producing oil or gas on a regular basis shall, with the exceptions noted below, be plugged and abandoned. 
(b)  The exceptions to the above paragraph are: 
(1)  Wells in use as water supply wells in compliance with rules and regulations of the Texas Water Quality Board and the RRC of the State of Texas. 
(2)  Wells in use as salt-water or waste-disposal wells which are operating under a valid permit from the governmental agency having authority, including, but not limited to, the permit required in section 19.5-52 of this chapter. 
(3)  Wells used as injection or observation wells in secondary recovery, pressure maintenance or other improved recovery operations where such operations are conducted under a valid permit from the RRC. 
(4)  Wells capable of producing oil or gas on a regular basis which are shut in due to lack of market or because of transfer of allowable permitted by the RRC. 
(5)  Any well on which drilling, reworking, recompletion, or well servicing operations are in progress and continued with no cessation of more than sixty (60) consecutive days. 
(6)  Such other wells where, within sixty (60) calendar days of the effective date, or within sixty (60) calendar days of the well's ceasing to produce oil or gas on a regular basis, the owner thereof files with the planning department an application for exception which includes the following: 
a.  Name of the owner of the well and the operator; 
b.  Surface location of the well by metes and bounds related to drilling block number; 
c.  Well bore diagram showing casing set, completion interval and down-hole equipment in the well if such information is available; 
d.  A surety bond in the amount of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) with good and sufficient corporate surety payable to the city, providing that the principal will plug said well in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. In lieu of said bond, cash in the amount of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) may be deposited with the city on the same conditions. A bond conditioned as provided in section 19.5-133 of this chapter shall also be filed unless such bond so conditioned is already on file and in effect. The bond shall be released when the well is plugged and abandoned, or when the superintendent has been satisfied that the well is again producing oil or gas on a regular basis, or when it meets one (1) of the conditions of exemption listed in subsections (3), (4) and (5) above; 
e.  A certificate of existence of public liability insurance in the amounts set out in section 19.5-132 of this chapter; 
f.  Date of RRC permit and copy of latest order of RRC pertaining to such well. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-86. - Abandonment procedures. 
(a)  Whenever any well is abandoned, it shall be the obligation of the operator to plug such well in accordance with the laws of the State of Texas, the rules of the RRC, the procedures outlined in this chapter, and/or any other agency having jurisdiction in connection with the abandonment or plugging of such well. The operator shall submit to the planning department forty-eight (48) hours in advance of the plugging operation a notice of intent to plug and abandon, which will include the abandonment program and a request for release of permit. The abandonment operations shall be conducted in such a manner as to prevent well fluids from reaching the surface or contaminating subsurface fresh water zones. The abandonment action shall not occur on any Saturday, Sunday, or city holiday. 
(b)  Where enough of the producing or protective casing has been removed from the well to expose the shoe of the surface casing, then a two-hundred-foot cement plug shall be placed opposite the shoe of the surface casing to extend at least one hundred (100) feet upwards from the shoe of the surface casing. Sufficient time shall be allowed for this cement to harden enough so that it will sustain the weight of drill pipe or tubing to this depth. The operator shall feel for the top of the plug to determine that the top is at least one hundred (100) feet above the shoe of the surface casing and is of sufficient hardness to hold the weight of the drill pipe or tubing to this depth. If a mechanical bridge plug or cement retainer is used in the middle of the cement plug, it will not be required to feel for the top of the plug. In the event the top of the plug is not one hundred (100) feet upwards from the shoe, then a second cement application will be required and tested as above. After the plug at the shoe has been successfully completed, then a minimum fifty-foot cement plug shall be set at the surface, after which the casing shall be cut off a minimum of five (5) feet below the surface of the ground and a one-half (1/2) inch steel plate welded over the top. A two-inch galvanized pipe shall be screwed into this collar so as to extend upwards three (3) feet above the surface. The location shall then be backfilled and leveled. 
(c)  Where the protective or producing string of casing to be left in the well extends upwards from the shoe of the surface casing so as to prevent the above-described method of abandonment, then the following procedure will be used. A packer of cast-iron cement retainer shall be set in the surface casing fifty (50) feet above the top of any other casing within the surface casing and sufficient cement shall then be squeezed below the packer or retainer to theoretically extend to one hundred (100) feet below the shoe of the surface casing and fill that portion up to the packer or retainer with the cement. The packer or retainer will be left in the well. A surface plug, as described above, will then be set and abandonment completed in the same manner as described in paragraph (b) above. 
(d)  Where well conditions prevent plugging of the well in accordance with above paragraphs (b) and (c) of this section, the operator shall plug and abandon such well using any alternate method which may be proposed by the operator and approved by the planning department. 
(e)  The planning department shall witness all plugging and abandonments and certify in writing that the abandonment was or was not in accordance with the above procedure. No permit will be released without certification that the plugging and abandonment was successfully accomplished in accordance with the above procedure. A plugging certificate will be issued by the planning department and a copy forwarded to the operator or owner of the plugged well. 
(f)  When a well has been plugged and abandoned in accordance with the above procedures and the permittee is entitled to a release of permit, the planning department will affix a proper identification marking to the two (2) inch riser, as required in paragraph (b) of this section, and make an office record thereof, so that ready reference to the office files will reflect the exact location of the well, date of abandonment, and condition of well at time of abandonment. It shall be unlawful to remove such marking or riser unless a permit to remove same is approved by the planning department. 
(g)  Whenever operations under paragraphs (b) and (c) of this section are employed, then the following further requirements will be complied with: 
(1)  When casing is to be shot or cut off and pulled, a blowout preventer equipped to completely blank off the well bore and close off around the casing to be pulled shall be installed and tested prior to shooting or cutting off the casing. 
(2)  In all cases prior to cutting any casing, the annulus between the casing to be recovered and the surface string of casing will be tested to determine whether this annulus is dead or pressured. In the event it is pressured, no casing will be recovered until this pressure is released to zero and the annulus filled with mud-laden fluid of sufficient density to maintain zero surface pressure. 
(3)  The well shall have a safety valve installed on the top of the casing string before any casing is shot or cut-off. This safety valve shall not be removed until the first joint of casing has been pulled and shall then be kept immediately at hand so that it may be reinstalled, if needed. 
(4)  The well shall be completely filled at all times with mud-laden fluid of sufficient density to prevent the entrance of formation fluids which would jeopardize well control during all casing and tubing operations. Periodic checks will be made of the mud fluid during displacing operations. 
(5)  The operator shall have a responsible representative at the well site during the setting and tagging of cement plugs and during the casing pulling operations to ensure that the procedures outlined in the notice of intent to plug and abandon filed with the RRC are complied with and to ensure that other provisions of this chapter are complied with. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Secs. 19.5-87-19.5-97. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TECHNICAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 19.5-98. - Pits. 
    The use of earthen pits for reserve mud or waste material such as drilling mud, contaminated mud, drill stem test returns and the like shall not be permitted. However, earthen pits may be used for storage of fresh water and for drill cuttings only. A sump pit may be constructed and used to collect and temporarily hold runoffs from the rig. Upon completion of any well, any earthen pits and sump pits shall be emptied, allowed to dry and filled with dirt and smooth-leveled with the grade of the drilling block. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-99. - Derricks and rigs. 
    No operator shall use or operate any wooden derrick in connection with the drilling or reworking of any well, or permit any drilling rig or derrick to remain on the premises or drilling site for a period longer than sixty (60) calendar days after completion or abandonment of any well. All engines shall be equipped with effective mufflers. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-100. - Drilling fluid. 
    The bore hole of any well, while being drilled or reworked, shall at all times contain drilling fluid of sufficient density which a reasonably prudent operator in the area would use to keep the well under control. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-101. - Blowout preventers. 
    Two (2) dually controlled, hydraulically activated blowout preventers with a manually operated lock with working-pressure rating equal to the maximum anticipated wellhead pressure, but at least equal to the minimum internal yield-pressure rating of the casing to which it is connected, shall be used for all drilling or completion operations involving the use of drill pipe or tubing after the surface casing has been set. For wells drilled to depths below nine thousand (9,000) feet, a Hydril-type blowout preventer shall be used in addition to the two (2) dually controlled blowout preventers above specified. The mechanical operation of the blowout preventers shall be checked a minimum of every twenty-four (24) hours and pressure-tested prior to installation on each casing string at least once a week thereafter during the drilling and completing point. A choke manifold having the same working-pressure rating as the preventers will be installed below the blowout preventer stack. In addition, the drilling rig, as part of its inventory, will have inside blowout preventers for each size and thread of tubing or drill pipe to be used in the drilling of said test well and any other type of safety equipment commonly used in the industry that may be requested by the superintendent. It is required that, upon obtaining a depth of three hundred (300) feet, a conductor lining or pipe be set and cemented to the bore hole throughout to the surface with attachment of adequate blowout preventers and testing thereof prior to drilling further. This shall be performed in the presence of the planning department and subject to any additional requirements which they may impose in this regard. Upon the witnessing by the planning department of such procedures, drilling operations may be continued. In the event the planning department is satisfied that the returns of cement to the surface cannot be obtained, then the planning department may approve alternate remedial procedures. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-102. - Surface casing. 
    All operators commencing drilling operations on a new well shall be required to set and cement a sufficient amount of surface casing to properly protect all fresh-water sands in accordance with the requirements of the Texas Water Development Board and any other governmental agency having jurisdiction. The length of surface casing shall in no case be less than fifteen hundredths (0.15) of the length of the next string of pipe proposed to be set. The surface casing shall be new or used casing, inspected and pressure-tested to have a minimum internal yield value, as defined by the API formula, of at least the product of one and zero tenths (1.0) pounds per square inch times the total depth of which the surface casing is set and shall be cemented by the pump-and-plug method. A volume of cement shall be used which, according to accepted engineering procedures, is calculated to fill the annular space between the surface casing and well bore to the surface of the ground. The cement will be circulated with the pump until the returns of cement are observed at the surface of the ground, and the cement shall be allowed to stand for a period sufficient to develop one thousand (1,000) pounds per square inch (psi) compressive strength before the plug is drilled. If cement does not circulate to the surface, then a temperature survey shall be conducted to determine the depth reached by the cement, and at such time such remedial procedures shall be followed as directed by the planning department. As to wells above four thousand (4,000) feet, the planning department shall have the authority to grant exceptions to the surface casing requirements, provided that the exception is based on written findings that include documentation as to the presence of protective measures that mitigate impacts to the public health and safety. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-103. - Setting and cementing casing. 
    No well shall be drilled within the city limits without properly setting a conductor string of casing to a minimum depth of three hundred (300) feet below the surface of the ground. No well shall be drilled without first cementing the casing string by the pump-and-plug method with sufficient cement to completely fill all of the annular space behind such string to the surface of the ground. The same method shall be used for the cementing of the surface string to the sides of the hole. The production and/or protection string shall be cemented by the pump-and-plug method with sufficient cement to completely fill all of the annual space behind the production string to at least one thousand (1,000) feet above the highest oil- and/or gas-bearing horizons. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-104. - Production and protection casing. 
    The producing or protection strings of casing, installed after the effective date, shall be of pipe meeting API specifications for new casing. Cementing shall be by the pump-and-plug method, and a volume of cement which is, according to accepted engineering calculations, sufficient to fill the annular space between the casing and well bore to a point at least one thousand (1,000) feet above the shoe, or the highest producing zone, whichever is the shallower depth. Cement shall be allowed to stand for a period sufficient to develop two thousand (2,000) psi compressive strength before drilling the plug. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-105. - Drill stem tests. 
(a)  No operator shall conduct or allow to be conducted any swabbing operations or the taking or completion of any drill stem test except during daylight hours. Drill stem tests may be conducted only if the well effluent produced during the test is produced through an adequate oil and gas separator to storage vessels, the gas placed into a temporary line to flow into the air at a place approved by the superintendent, and the effluent remaining in the drill pipe at the time the tool is closed is flushed to the surface by circulating drilling fluid down the annulus and up the drill pipe. The planning department may shut down operations if, in the opinion of the department, gas which is excessive or dangerous is being flared by the operator. An exception to the requirements of this paragraph may be granted by the fire department. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to conduct open-hold drill stem tests within the city limits. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-106. - Formation pressures. 
    No well shall be completed or operated in a zone which is reasonably anticipated to produce shut-in pressures in excess of the working-pressure rating of the standard API wellhead equipment of the well. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-107. - Wellheads. 
    All wells drilled or completed after the effective date will be equipped with casing heads, tubing heads, and wellhead connections which conform to API standards. The casing heads used on such wells shall have working-pressure ratings of not less than the highest pressure encountered in the area. All blow-out preventers, also referred to as Christmas trees, to be used by the operator in the city limits shall have to be tested to the related pressure before the same is installed, and a copy of such testing shall be furnished to the planning department. The planning department shall have to approve tubing heads and wellhead connections to be used on such wells which shall have working-pressure ratings in excess of the well's shut-in surface pressure. All such wells having a surface shut-in pressure of three thousand (3,000) pounds per square inch or less shall be equipped with at least one (1) master valve and one (1) wing valve. All wells having surface shut-in pressures in excess of three thousand (3,000) pounds per square inch shall be equipped with at least two (2) master valves and wing valves, and no such well shall have threaded connections between the surface safety valve and the Christmas tree. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-108. - Multiple completions. 
    Multiple completions may be permitted by the planning department when the department is satisfied that the casing, tubing and wellhead equipment is adequate and that the well is properly equipped with special packers for such purposes together with all equipment customarily required for multiple completions. Except as provided in this section, multiple completions shall not be permitted. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-109. - Surface safety valves. 
    A high-low surface safety valve shall be installed on all wells with a surface shut-in pressure in excess of one thousand five hundred (1,500) pounds per square inch (psi). In addition, a cutoff safety valve will be installed down stream from the wellhead equipment, or as directed by the planning department. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-110. - Well control; authority of planning department to regain control of well; lien to secure payment of expenditures. 
    In the event of the loss of control of any well, the operator shall immediately implement steps to regain control of such well, and shall notify the planning department as soon as practicable after the occurrence of such loss of well control endangering persons or property. If and when the planning department certifies in writing to the city secretary that, in their opinion, danger to persons or property exists because of such loss of well control, briefly describing the same, and the operator is not taking, or is unable to take, all reasonably necessary steps to regain control of such well, the planning department or the railroad commission may employ any well-control expert or experts or other contractors or suppliers of special services, or may incur any other expense for labor or material which the planning department or the railroad commission deems necessary to regain control of such well. The city shall place a valid lien against the property for all working interest and leasehold owners who have voluntarily joined in the drilling of such well to secure payment of any expenditure made by the city and/or the railroad commission or its agent, pursuant to any such action of the railroad commission and/or the city in regaining control of any such well. A lien shall also attach to the interest in the well of those persons who have been presumed to have elected to participate as carried interest owners under article VII of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-111. - Relief wells; permit; filing fee; completion as producing well. 
(a)  Drilling of an emergency relief well may be commenced without first securing a permit if such action is deemed necessary by the planning department. The operator shall make all reasonable efforts to notify the planning department as soon as feasible. Within twenty-four (24) hours after the commencement of operations for the drilling of such a relief well, the operator drilling the same shall notify the planning department that such operations have been commenced, stating fully the reasons therefore, and shall within five (5) calendar days after commencement of operations make application to the [planning department] for a special permit to drill said well as a relief well. 
(b)  A two thousand five hundred dollar ($2,500.00) filing fee is required for a relief well permit, and the operator drilling such relief well shall furnish the planning department any information with respect to such relief well as required by article IV. 
(c)  No such well drilled as a relief well under the provisions of this section shall be completed as a producing well unless a permit therefore shall have been issued in the same manner as is required under article IV of this chapter for the drilling of any other well. A relief well permit will be for a six-month period only, and any relief well not completed as a producing well shall be plugged and abandoned within six (6) months after commencement of drilling operations, unless an extension is granted by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-112. - Pipelines; franchise for; required information. 
    Before any excavation or construction work is commenced on any pipeline to move oil, gas, water or other product to or from any well site, on, over, under, along or across any city street, sidewalk, alley or other city property, a franchise shall first be obtained from the city council. All pipelines shall be laid only in accordance with the provisions of such franchise, this chapter, the city charter and other ordinances of the city. Before a franchise is obtained from the city council, the parties requesting such franchise shall present information to the city pertaining to the safety equipment to be used in the pipeline, the type of pipe to be used, and how the same compares to state and federal regulations for similar type pipelines to be operated within a city. All permanent pipelines constructed after the effective date, and replacement of any part of any pipeline existing at the date of this chapter, shall be composed of new pipe or of used tested pipe meeting American Society of Mechanical Engineers specification A.S.A. 331.8 or better. Any operator constructing a pipeline shall furnish the planning department a centerline description plat showing the proposed and as-built location and size of such pipeline. No operator shall interfere with or damage any existing storm sewer, drainage facility, water line, sewer line or gas line, or facility of a public utility located on, under or across the course of any such pipeline. Temporary lines may be laid under revocable easements. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-113. - Storage facilities; standards. 
    Steel storage tanks shall be used for the storage of liquid hydrocarbons and shall be constructed, installed and maintained in a good condition pursuant to the criteria set forth in the International Fire Code (IFC). All such steel tanks installed after the effective date shall meet the minimum quality and design standards of API 12B standard bolted steel tanks or API 12D standard welded steel tanks including recommended pressure and vacuum relief valves. All such tanks shall be equipped with a vent line and, at the point where gas is vented to the atmosphere from said vent line, a flame arrester shall be installed. Each tank, or tank battery as the case may be, shall be surrounded by an earthen fire wall located at such a distance from the tanks and of sufficient height to hold and retain at least one and one-half (11/2) times the maximum capacity of such storage facilities. An operator may use, construct and operate steel conventional separators and such other appurtenances as are reasonably necessary for treating oil, condensate, or gas at each tank battery location. Such facilities shall be constructed and maintained so as to meet or exceed API standards. Each oil and gas separator shall be equipped with both a regulation pressure relief safety valve and a bursting head. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-114. - Fired vessels. 
    No fired vessel or open flame shall be located nearer than one hundred fifty (150) feet from any well or storage tank. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-115. - Fences. 
    All wells and production facilities shall be adequately protected by a cyclone-type fence of heavy gauge wire, at least six (6) feet tall with an eighteen (18) inch or longer barbed wire apron around the top, with the fence and apron extended over entry gates. The entry gates shall be galvanized steel and cyclone-type mesh, and shall be kept locked at all times, except when passing through the same. However, any wellhead, tank battery, pumping unit or equipment appurtenant thereto, located on any lease, tract or farm, which, as determined by the planning department, is adequately fenced in its entirety will require no additional fencing. Flashing red warning lights shall be installed as required by the planning department on the tank battery sites. Industry standard safety precautions shall be observed. The final design of the fence around the wells and production facilities shall be reviewed and approved by the planning department. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-116. - Pumping unit prime movers. 
    Only electric prime movers shall be permitted for the purpose of pumping wells. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-117. - Vented gas. 
    No operator shall allow gas to escape or be vented into the air except for bleed gas normally vented from standard gas-operated controls and normal stock tank vapors. All gas burned shall be burned in a manner which does not create or constitute a fire hazard and the location of the torch, pipe or other burning device, the construction, maintenance, and operation thereof shall at all times be in full compliance with such regulations as may be from time to time issued by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-118. - Salt-water and waste-water disposal. 
    All salt water produced from any oil or gas well shall be disposed of underground provided a proper permit is obtained therefore in accordance with section 19.5-52 of this chapter, unless a permit to dispose of the water by some other method is approved by the RRC. The city, in such event, may furnish the operator a revisable easement upon the operator's meeting the requirements of the city. No person shall permit any crude oil, gas or other flammable petroleum product to spill over, overflow, leak, drain out, escape or accumulate in any sewer or about the premises, or on any surface, or in any open surface ditch or any other exposed surface conduit, or handle any hydrocarbon in any manner or amount which creates a potential fire hazard, or permit any condition which may pollute any surface or subsurface water or damage any publicly owned land. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-119. - Secondary recovery and pressure maintenance. 
    Equipment installed for the purpose of performing secondary recovery, pressure maintenance or other improved recovery operations, or for automatic lease operations, shall comply with all safety regulations of all ordinances of the city and the rules of the RRC. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-120. - Signs. 
    Printed signs with at least two-inch letters reading "DANGER, NO SMOKING OR OPEN FLAMES ALLOWED," or similar words, and in Spanish, "PELIGRO, NO FUMAR, MATERIAL COMBUSTIBLE," or similar words, shall be posted in conspicuous places on each well, storage tank or battery of tanks. The signs shall include well name, drilling block number and notification telephone number of the Eagle Pass Fire Department. Well and lease designations required by the RRC or any other governmental authority having jurisdiction shall also be displayed. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-121. - Blocking of streets and alleys. 
    No street or alley shall be blocked or obstructed by any drilling or producing operations unless prior written consent is obtained from the city, except in connection with emergency operations being conducted pursuant to sections 19.5-110 and 19.5-111. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Secs. 19.5-122-19.5-131. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - INSURANCE AND BONDS 

Sec. 19.5-132. - Insurance requirements. 
(a)  All operators shall maintain or cause to be maintained public liability insurance and insurance coverage on their employees, agents, and contractors (or require such insurance to be maintained), in addition to required workmen's compensation insurance, in the following minimum amounts: 
(1)  Comprehensive general liability insurance. Public liability (bodily injury) insurance with limits of not less than three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for each person, and for each accident in the aggregate; 
(2)  Public liability (property damage) insurance with limits of not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for each accident and one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for any number of accidents; 
(3)  Umbrella insurance for the amount of three million dollars ($3,000,000.00). 
    Said insurance policies shall name the city as an additional named insured. The coverage in such insurance policies shall be approved by the city and may only exclude as a risk damage to the reservoir and pollution. 
(b)  The operator may furnish the planning department with an insurance certificate showing that the operator has insurance to cover the expense of "well out of control" with no limits as to cost. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-133. - Bond requirements. 
(a)  Each applicant shall file a bond with the planning department executed by the applicant as principal and by a good and sufficient corporate surety company. Said bond shall provide that the principal will remedy any and all damages to the streets, curbs, gutters, water lines, fire hydrants and other public property, occasioned in any manner by the principal, their agents, employees, servants and contractors, and that the applicant will reimburse the city for any expenditures made by the city under the authority granted in section 19.5-110 of this chapter. Such bonds shall inure to the benefit of the city, shall be in a form acceptable to the city attorney, and shall be in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00). The applicant shall not be required to post additional bond if they have in effect and on file with the planning department an approved bond, filed in connection with some other application for the same applicant, in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) as required by this section. Each bond shall be for a term of ten (10) years and shall be kept in effect by renewal on or before any expiration date unless the applicant is sooner released by the planning department. 
(b)  In the event the applicant does not have insurance to cover the expense of "well out of control" as set out in section 19.5-132(b), they shall provide a bond with the planning department executed by the applicant and by a good and sufficient corporate company. Said bond shall provide that the principal will remedy any and all damages and expenses incurred by the city in regaining control of oil or gas wells while being drilled and tested and/or any other wells which get out of control which are operated by the operator and are situated within the city limits. Such expense will only cover the cost of materials and supplies required, and the services of individuals or firms specializing in the controlling of wells including the directional drilling and similar operations necessary to bring the wells under control. A well shall be deemed out of control only so long as there is a continuous flow of drilling fluid, oil, gas or water above the surface of the ground which is uncontrollable. Such bond shall inure to the benefit of the city and shall be in a form acceptable to the city attorney and shall be in the amount of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00). The applicant shall not be required to post this "well out of control" bond if they have in effect and on file with the planning department a certificate of insurance showing that they have well-control insurance with a deductible of not more than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00). Each bond shall be for a term of at least one (1) year, and shall be kept in effect by renewal on or before any expiration date unless the applicant is sooner released by the planning department after the drilling operations have been completed and the well has been completed as a producer or plugged and abandoned. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-134. - Release of bonds and permits. 
    The city council may release bonds and permits, as to the city, under the following conditions: 
(1)  When the permittee ceases all operations covered by this chapter, all wells for which the permittee holds permits have been plugged in accordance with the terms hereof, including the removal of all equipment and machinery, and files a request for release with the city council, the council shall furnish a release, as to the city, of all the permittee's bonds pertaining to the particular well. 
(2)  If the permittee assigns all of their interest in the drilling block, production block or production unit covered by a bond or bonds, such assignor shall be released from such bond as to that drilling or production block or production unit, except as to any liability then existing, after the assignee has fully complied with the bond and insurance requirements of this chapter, and the issuance of a substitute permit under section 19.5-61 shall constitute a release of the original permit. 
(3)  Any permittee who has plugged and abandoned a well in accordance with the requirements of this chapter and complied with all other requirements of the chapter may, upon request to the council, be furnished a release of the permit pertaining to such well. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-135. - Bond surety. 
    By the term "good and sufficient corporate surety company" is meant a surety company licensed to do business in the State of Texas and whose name appears on the current list of accepted surety of federal bonds published by the United States Treasury Department. Whenever in this chapter a bond is mentioned, such bond, to be acceptable, must have a good and sufficient corporate surety company as surety. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Secs. 19.5-136-19.5-145. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - UNITIZATION 

Sec. 19.5-146. - Purpose. 
    In order to facilitate the orderly development of oil and gas production in the city and to avoid confiscation of property, owners of oil and gas interests permitted to be unitized in article II shall be given the opportunity to participate in the production of oil and gas from the drilling block in which their property is located subject to the rules provided in this article and article II of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-147. - Procedure for unitization. 
    The procedure outlined herein for the unitization of oil and gas interests is not intended to be an exclusive method for unitizing such interests. Voluntary unitization is authorized and encouraged as a substitute for the procedures outlined herein. A voluntary unitization agreement between the various owners will satisfy the unitization requirements contained in this chapter insofar as they relate to those owners signing said unitization agreement. If voluntary agreements cannot be reached with all of the owners of oil and gas interests within the drilling block to be unitized, the procedure for unitizing all interests in such drilling block or blocks not voluntarily unitized or owned by the applicant shall be as follows: 
(a)  The applicant shall file application to drill in accordance with the terms and provisions of article IV hereof, including the names and addresses of all owners of operating rights within the production block or blocks covered by the application. 
(b)  Owners of operating rights shall be entitled to the following options: 
(1)  Mineral fee owner. A mineral fee owner of an oil and gas interest not covered by an existing oil and gas lease shall be entitled to participate as a royalty owner on the basis of: 
a.  One-sixth ( 1/6 ) royalty; or 
b.  One-eighth ( 1/8 ) royalty plus a bonus equal to the highest bonus paid by the operator in the production block where the mineral interest to be unitized is situated. 
    Such election is to be made in a letter addressed to the planning department before the permit is approved by the city council. If no letter is received, it will be considered that the owner has elected subsection a. above. In addition, said mineral fee owner shall be entitled to elect between the options available to the lessee as referenced in subsection (b)(2) below; however, if said mineral fee owner fails to elect between the options available to the lessee within thirty (30) calendar days from the date of publication of the notice required in section 19.5-148, they shall be conclusively presumed to have elected to participate under a royalty clause as provided above. If any such mineral owner owns an interest in the oil and gas on, in and under said land less than the entire fee simple oil and gas mineral estate, then the royalty participation of such mineral owner, and such owner's share of participation as an operating owner or as a carried interest owner under either Option No. 1 or 2 below, shall be reduced in the proportion that their interest bears to the whole and undivided fee and in accordance with the nature of the estate of which they are seized. 
(2)  Lessee. The lessee shall be entitled to elect between the following options: 
    Option No. 1. The lessee may elect within thirty (30) calendar days from the date of posting said notice to participate in the drilling and production of the well as an active operating interest owner, in which event they shall pay their proportionate share of all drilling and operating costs and shall participate in production in proportion to this ownership in the production block. If such owner elects to participate as an operating owner, they shall either post bond, written by an approved bonding company as provided in section 19.5-135, or deposit cash with the applicant guaranteeing payment to the applicant of such operating interest owner's proportionate share on a surface acreage basis of the following amounts: 
a.  The estimated cost of drilling and completing the well; and 
b.  The estimated monthly operating expenses. 
    If the cost of drilling and completing the well exceeds the estimated cost, such owner shall forthwith on demand pay their proportionate share of the excess to the applicant, or if the actual costs are less than the estimate, such owner's proportionate share of the difference shall be refunded by the applicant on demand. Such operating interest owner shall advance to the applicant, at monthly or other mutually acceptable intervals, such owner's share of estimated expenses of operating the production unit or, at the election of applicant, such owner's share of the operating expenses may be deducted by the applicant from revenues from production which otherwise would be payable to such owner as such expenses accrue. 
    Option No. 2. The lessee may elect to become the owner of a carried interest. If the lessee elects to be a carried interest owner, they shall not be entitled to receive any revenue from their interest in the production block until such time as the participating owners have received from the proceeds of production attributable to said carried interest owner's leasehold interest an amount equal to their proportionate share of current operating expenses, the cost of purchasing and installing all pipelines, tank batteries and other equipment installed by the participating owners to facilitate production of oil and gas from said production block, and an amount equal to twice said carried interest owner's proportionate share of the cost of drilling and completing a well drilled on said production block. The interest of such a carried interest owner shall be subject to its proportionate share of all operating costs incurred by the operating owners and properly allocable to the production block in accordance with accepted accounting practices. Any remaining income attributable to said carried interest shall be payable to the owner thereof monthly. 
    If a lessee fails to elect to participate under one (1) of the two (2) options shown above within thirty (30) calendar days after the date of posting notice to such interest owner of operator's intent to unitize said unit, then and in that event such lessee shall be presumed to have elected to participate as a carried interest owner under Option 2 above. The operator shall furnish the lessee, upon the lessee's request, copies of their authority for expenditure for the drilling and completion of said well and an estimate of monthly operating expenses. In addition, the operator shall furnish the lessee an operating agreement under which the operator will be designated as "operator," and such operating agreement will have an accounting procedure attached to it and made a part thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-148. - Notice to owners; form; publication. 
(a)  Notice will be given to the owners whose addresses are known or are ascertainable by use of ordinary diligence. It will be presumed that an operator has used ordinary diligence if they have checked the city tax records to obtain the address listed therein for the owner of the oil and gas interests within the affected drilling and production block or blocks which are not under lease to the applicant and which are not covered by voluntary unitization agreements. 
(b)  Notice shall be given as follows: 
(1)  The applicant shall deliver or send by certified mail to all such owners, at their last known address, a written notice which shall include the following: 
a.  A legal description of the proposed drilling block, production block or production unit. 
b.  The drilling block number in which the proposed well is to be located. 
c.  Type of interest held by the owner being notified (royalty under existing lease, mineral fee, lessee, overriding royalty, etc.). 
d.  A statement of the options available to the owner being notified, if any, as set out in this article at section 19.5-147, if applicable. 
e.  Notification that if the owner fails to notify the applicant in writing within thirty (30) calendar days from the date of posting of said notice to each owner of the selection of one (1) of the available options, the owner will be conclusively presumed to have elected to participate as a carried interest owner as set out in section 19.5-147(b), and if a mineral owner, under section 19.5-147(b)(1)a. 
(2)  In addition to the individual notification provided for above, the applicant will cause to be published in the newspaper published in the city a notice in substantial compliance with the following form: 
    "Notice is hereby given that (name) of (address), as applicant, pursuant to the provisions of the Oil and Gas Drilling Ordinance of the City of Eagle Pass, will, on or about the ________ day of _________, 20__, file with the City Planning Department, an application for a permit to drill and/or operate a well, upon Drilling Block No. ________, and Production Block No. ________, a general description of which are as follows: 
_____
_____
_____
    A map showing the lands comprising said drilling and production blocks and the exterior boundaries thereof is on file in the Planning Department and is at said office subject to examination by all persons during regular office hours. All interests within the production block will be unitized pursuant to Article VII of the Oil and Gas Drilling Ordinance. Owners of operating rights in land to be unitized have the option of (1) participating in the drilling and production of the well as active operating interest owners, or (2) becoming a carried interest owner. Owners who do not notify the applicant in writing of their election of one (1) of the options available within thirty (30) calendar days of the date of this publication will be conclusively presumed to have elected to participate as a carried interest owner as provided in section 19.5-147(b) of the City of Eagle Pass Code of Ordinances." 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-149. - Allocation of production. 
    Production from such unitized production blocks or production units shall be allocated to tracts which are unitized under the provisions of this article in the proportions that the surface acreage of each such individual tract has to the total surface acreage in the production block or production unit. Owners of interests under such tracts shall be allocated production on the basis of their interest therein. Production from the production block or production unit in which said owner participates shall be treated as production from all of the tracts within said production block or production unit. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Sec. 19.5-150. - Contracts between permittee and other owners. 
    The permittee and owners of other mineral interests in any production block or production unit shall be able to alter the obligations as set out in this article by an agreement made by them in writing, provided such agreement is not in conflict with other provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 3-18-2014) 
Chapter 20 - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS 
ARTICLE I. - PERMIT FOR ITINERANT MERCHANTS AND VENDORS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2011-13, § 1, adopted Aug. 2, 2011, repealed the former Art. I, §§ 20-1-20-15, and enacted a new Art. I as set out herein. The former Art. I pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the original codification, as amended by Ord. No. 87-07, 6-2-1987. 

Sec. 20-1. - Purpose and construction of article. 
    This entire article is and shall be deemed an exercise of the police power of the city for the public safety, comfort, convenience and protection of the city and the citizens thereof, and all of the provisions of this article shall be construed for the accomplishment of that purpose. 
(Ord. No. 2011-13, § 1, 8-2-2011) 
Sec. 20-2. - Definitions. 
(a)  For the purposes of this article, an "itinerant merchant" or an "itinerant vendor" is any person or agent or employee of the person who goes from house to house or from place to place in the city soliciting, selling or taking orders for or offering to sell or take orders for any personal property, goods, wares, merchandise, services, photographs or magazines, or who engages in a temporary business of selling, offering to sell, exhibiting and/or delivering any personal property, goods, wares, merchandise, or services, or who conducts meetings open to the general public where franchises, distributorships, contracts or business opportunities are offered to participants. An "itinerant merchant" or an "itinerant vendor" also means any person or agent or employee of the person who displays, exhibits, sells or offers for sale any personal property, goods, merchandise, service upon or from a truck, a cart, or other vehicle on non-residential property located in the city, or who hires, rents, leases or occupies an area in any lot, structure, enclosure, or any other property in the city that does not require a certificate of occupancy through or from which any goods or merchandise may be sold, offered for sale, exhibited for sale or exhibited for the purpose of taking orders for the sale thereof. 
(b)  "Moral turpitude" shall mean an act or behavior that violates the sentiment or accepted standard of the community, or a quality of dishonesty or other immorality that is determined by a court to be present in the commission of a criminal offense. Moral turpitude offenses include, but are not limited to, sexual assault of a child, lying to a police officer, mail fraud, tax evasion, prostitution, purchase of a child, indecent exposure, failure to stop and render aid, theft, aggravated assault, assault by a male on a female, communicating a false alarm, murder and indecent exposure, and bank fraud. 
(Ord. No. 2011-13, § 1, 8-2-2011) 
Sec. 20-3. - General duties of the planning department. 
    The administration for the processing of permits authorized pursuant to this article shall be performed by the director of the planning department or his/her designee (department). The planning department shall perform all duties incumbent upon it under the terms of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2011-13, § 1, 8-2-2011) 
Sec. 20-4. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any itinerant merchant or vendor to engage in any activity described in subsection 20-2(a) without a valid permit. 
(Ord. No. 2011-13, § 1, 8-2-2011) 
Sec. 20-5. - Application-Generally. 
    Any person required to have a permit shall make written application to the planning department that contains the following information: 
(1)  The full name of the applicant. 
(2)  The residence and mailing address of applicant. 
(3)  The age, height, weight, complexion, color of hair and color of eyes of the applicant. 
(4)  The occupation in which the applicant desires to engage and for which he desires a permit. 
(5)  A full and complete description of all the personal property, goods, wares and merchandise or other articles or tokens which applicant desires to display, exhibit, sell or offer for sale, which description shall give in detail the grade and character of the property to be sold. 
(6)  Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a felony or a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude. 
(7)  State of Texas sales tax certificate number for applicant. 
(Ord. No. 2011-13, § 1, 8-2-2011) 
Sec. 20-6. - Same-Attachments. 
    There shall be attached to each application for a permit under this article the following: 
(1)  Two (2) recent photographs of the applicant that do not exceed one (1) inch square in size. 
(2)  A sworn statement from the president, a vice president, general manager, sales manager, assistant sales manager or district or area manager of the company for which the applicant works, sells or solicits, verifying that the applicant is an employee and/or agent of such company. 
(3)  A reference to a recognized financial rating publication that shows the page on which the company's or firm's financial standing can be found; or a letter or a certificate from an association or organization which has as its purpose the protection of citizens of the United States against illegal or unsavory business practices stating that the firm or company is a member in good standing of such association or organization. Alternatively, a certified copy of the entities permit to conduct business in the State of Texas. In the event that the applicant is an individual who is not working, selling or soliciting for any firm or company, letters of recommendation from two (2) citizens of the applicant's permanent residence shall be submitted. 
(4)  A notarized statement of authorization from a property owner is required for any applicant that intends to: (1) operate from upon or from a truck, a cart, or other vehicle on non-residential property located in the city; or (2) hire, rent, lease or occupy an area in any lot, structure, enclosure, or any other property in the city that does not require a certificate of occupancy through or from which any goods or merchandise may be sold, offered for sale, exhibited for sale or exhibited for the purpose of taking orders for the sale thereof. The statement of authorization must accompany the application and include: (1) term of the applicants consent to operate on the property; (2) the owner's name, address, and phone number; and (3) specific permission for each person to operate as an "itinerant merchant" or an "itinerant vendor" on the property. 
(5)  A copy of the applicant's driver's license, official state identification card, passport or other official forms of identification that are recognized by the IRS for employment verification purposes. 
(6)  A signed consent form to conduct a background investigation. 
(Ord. No. 2011-13, § 1, 8-2-2011) 
Sec. 20-7. - Processing of the permit application. 
    Upon the filing of an application for a permit under this article, the planning department will review the application pursuant to the provisions of this article and render a determination, after conducting a background investigation, to either grant or deny the permit within thirty (30) calendar [days] from the receipt of the a complete application. If the planning department fails to process the application within the required period, the application is denied. 
(Ord. No. 2011-13, § 1, 8-2-2011) 
Sec. 20-8. - Fee. 
    Each applicant for a permit under this article shall be charged a permit processing fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). Non-profit organizations are exempt from payment of the permit processing fee upon submittal of proof on non-profit status. 
(Ord. No. 2011-13, § 1, 8-2-2011) 
Sec. 20-9. - Issuance. 
    If, upon the completion of a review of the application by the planning department, the department finds that: (1) the statements contained in an application for a permit under this article are true; (2) the applicant has complied with the terms of this article (i.e. no violations, revocations or suspension of the permit); and (3) the applicant has not been convicted of a felony or a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude, then the planning department shall issue such permit to the applicant. Permits are not transferrable or assignable. 
(Ord. No. 2011-13, § 1, 8-2-2011) 
Sec. 20-10. - Contents. 
    Each permit issued under this article shall contain the following: 
(1)  The name of the applicant and his address. 
(2)  A physical description of the applicant. 
(3)  A photographic image of the applicant. 
(4)  The date the permit was issued and the date it expires. 
(Ord. No. 2011-13, § 1, 8-2-2011) 
Sec. 20-11. - Unlawful conduct. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any itinerant merchant or vendor to engage in any activity for which a permit is required by this article, unless he displays a lawfully issued permit on his person while so engaged. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any itinerant merchant or vendor to engage in any activity for which a permit is required by this article on Sunday or from 6:00 p.m. to 10:00 a.m. Monday through Saturday. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for any itinerant merchant or vendor to engage in any activity for which a permit is required by this article, on city property or right-of-way. 
(4)  It shall be unlawful for any itinerant merchant or vendor to operate on property where a conspicuous sign is posted that prohibits or states "no solicitors." 
    The department, any law enforcement or code enforcement officer may enforce the provisions of this article. 
    Wherever in this article an act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, or wherever in this article the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, the violation of any such provision of this article shall be a Class "C" misdemeanor punishable by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) per violation. 
(Ord. No. 2011-13, § 1, 8-2-2011) 
Sec. 20-12. - Duration. 
    All permits issued under this article shall be valid for a period of one (1) year, unless sooner revoked as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2011-13, § 1, 8-2-2011) 
Sec. 20-13. - Revocation and renewal. 
    If, after the permit provided for in this article has been issued, the planning department finds that the permit was obtained by false representation in the application, such permit may be revoked and/or not renewed by the planning department. Such permit may also be revoked and/or not renewed if it shall appear to the planning department that the holder of such permit has: (1) violated any provisions of this article or any ordinance of the city; or (2) been convicted of a felony or a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude. 
(Ord. No. 2011-13, § 1, 8-2-2011) 
Sec. 20-14. - Appeals from decisions of the planning department. 
    If the applicant for a permit under this article or the holder of such a permit is dissatisfied with any finding of the planning department, he or she shall have the right to appeal to the city council by filing a written notice of such appeal with the planning department within ten (10) days from the making of such decision by the planning department and paying the appeal fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00). Upon the filing of such notice of appeal, the application for the permit and all papers possessed by the planning department in connection with such application and such permit shall be delivered to the city council, and such matters as may be in dispute shall be heard by the council at its next regular meeting after the filing of the notice of appeal. The city council shall have the same powers and authority at such hearing on such appeal as is vested in the planning department by this article. 
(Ord. No. 2011-13, § 1, 8-2-2011) 
Sec. 20-15. - Exemptions from article. 
    The department may grant an exemption in writing for the sale or soliciting of orders for the sale of milk, dairy products, bakery products, vegetables, poultry, eggs and other farm and garden products which have been raised or produced by the vendor; daily deliveries of milk and bakery and other food products; newspaper and web page service or distribution when headquarters are maintained in the City of Eagle Pass; sales made to dealers by commercial travelers or sales agents in the usual course of business; sales made by distributors of any merchandise; any person acting as and licensed as a food peddler as provided in article III, chapter 20 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Eagle Pass; any non-profit organization; any person engaged wholly in interstate commerce or anyone whose operations form an integral part of interstate commerce and upon whom the provisions of this article would impose a direct and unlawful burden with respect to such operations; or sales made under authority and by order of law. 
    Public and private school related fundraisers are fully exempt from all requirements of this article. It is a defense to criminal prosecution if a defendant proves that he/she qualifies for an exemption. 
(Ord. No. 2011-13, § 1, 8-2-2011) 
Secs. 20-16-20-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 09-01, § 1, adopted Jan. 6, 2009, repealed the former Art. II, §§ 20-26-20-35, and enacted a new Art. II as set out herein. The former Art. II pertained to similar subject matter. See also the Code Comparative Table. 
Cross reference- Restrictions on carnivals for charitable purposes, § 19-3. 

Sec. 20-26. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit or obtain alms or gifts for any person, charitable organization, patriotic organization, or philanthropic organization, or to promote or participate in any entertainment, fair or bazaar in the name of charity, patriotism, or philanthropy, or to solicit or accept gifts or any property for any religious or missionary purpose, except by such organization on its own premises, without first obtaining a permit approved by the chief of police or his designee. The chief of police or his designee shall designate from time to time at least one (1) area of public property, within the city limits, which may be used to conduct charitable solicitations. 
(Ord. No. 09-01, § 1, 1-6-2009) 
Sec. 20-27. - Misrepresentations prohibited; causing a child to solicit from occupants of vehicles prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit or obtain alms or gifts in money or merchandise, directly or indirectly, by the misrepresentation of name, occupation, financial condition, social condition or residence. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a person to knowingly cause a child fourteen (14) years of age or younger to stand on a traffic median, shoulder, improved shoulder or sidewalk and solicit, or attempt to solicit charitable contributions from the occupants of any vehicle on a roadway. 
(Ord. No. 09-01, § 1, 1-6-2009) 
Sec. 20-28. - Audit required at close of solicitation. 
    Any applicant receiving a permit under this article to solicit funds in the city shall, at the close of the solicitation or within five (5) business days of the end of the permit term, file with the chief of police or his designee an audit made by a certified public accountant or, in lieu thereof, a sworn official statement containing an accounting of the funds received and the disbursement thereof. The accounting of the disbursement of funds received shall include wages, costs and all other expenses associated with the solicitation, if any and payments, donations, contributions and all other expenditures made or anticipated from the revenue of the permitted solicitation activities. Failure to submit said audit or sworn statement shall be grounds for denial of a future permit until such requirement is fulfilled. 
(Ord. No. 09-01, § 1, 1-6-2009) 
Sec. 20-29. - Application. 
    Each applicant for a permit under this article shall submit to the chief of police or his designee, at least five (5) business days before the proposed date(s) of solicitation, a sworn statement containing the following information: 
(1)  The name, address, of the applicant and the name, address, age, and sex of each individual soliciting on behalf of the applicant (solicitors). 
(2)  If the applicant is an organization, the names and addresses of the officers of its governing board. 
(3)  The percentage, if any, to be paid to the solicitors. 
(4)  The name of person(s): 
a.  For whose benefit the solicitation is to be made or, if an organization, the officials of the organization for whose support the permit is asked; 
b.  The names of the individual(s) who has authority to execute the sworn official statement of accounting of funds described in section 20-28 of this article; and 
c.  The names of the individual(s) who has authority to determine how the proceeds of the permitted charitable solicitation may be applied or utilized. 
(Ord. No. 09-01, § 1, 1-6-2009) 
Sec. 20-30. - Issuance. 
    If the chief of police or his designee finds that: 
(1)  The applicant and its solicitors meets all the requirements of this article; 
(2)  The applicant is in good standing with the Texas Secretary of State, where applicable; 
(3)  The applicant and its solicitors has complied with all the terms of this article within the last two (2) years; and 
(4)  The area of public property designated by the chief of police or his designee to conduct charitable solicitation is available, he/she shall issue such a permit. 
(Ord. No. 09-01, § 1, 1-6-2009) 
Sec. 20-31. - Permit term. 
    A permit issued under this article shall be dated and signed by the chief of police or his designee and may be issued to any person or organization no more than four (4) permits per calendar year for a period of no more than two (2) consecutive days and for no hours other than those between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 09-01, § 1, 1-6-2009) 
Sec. 20-32. - Transfer. 
    The solicitation permit prescribed by this article shall be nontransferable and shall have endorsed thereon in red letters the words "NOT TRANSFERABLE." 
(Ord. No. 09-01, § 1, 1-6-2009) 
Sec. 20-33. - Display; permittee to supply solicitors with credentials and be responsible for acts of solicitors. 
(a)  Each person receiving a permit under this article to beg or solicit funds on the city streets or within the city limits shall keep his permit prominently displayed about his person or on his vehicle. Each permit holder shall supply any solicitor used by him with proper credentials and the recipient of the permit shall be responsible for the overt acts of his representatives in connection with the solicitation authorized by the permit. 
(b)  All solicitors with a valid permit must wear a fluorescent visibility vest, must not impede traffic, and shall enter or remain in a roadway only while the controlling traffic signal prohibits vehicle movement. 
(Ord. No. 09-01, § 1, 1-6-2009) 
Sec. 20-34. - Effect; revocation; and appeal. 
    No permit granted under this article shall operate as a grant or a privilege or mature into a right, but such permit may be revoked at any time by the chief of police or his designee. 
    If a permit under this article is denied or revoked, the applicant shall have the right to appeal to the city manager by filing a written notice of appeal identifying the grounds for the appeal with the chief of police or his designee within five (5) business days from the date of the denial or revocation of a permit under this article. Upon the filing of such notice of appeal, the application for the permit, notice of appeal and all papers possessed by the chief of police or his designee in connection with such application and such permit shall be delivered to the city manager, and such matter shall be heard, as soon as practical, but in no event shall the time period exceed thirty (30) days after the filing of the notice of appeal. The city manager shall consider the appeal based on the substantial evidence standard and it/he shall have the same powers and authority at such hearing on such appeal as is vested in the chief of police or his designee by this article. The decision of the city manager is final and nonappealable. 
(Ord. No. 09-01, § 1, 1-6-2009) 
Sec. 20-35. - Records to be kept. 
    The chief of police or his designee shall keep a map or other description of the designated area(s) for charitable solicitations and each application for a permit under this article on file, together with a record of its action thereon, subject to the inspection by any person, at any reasonable time. 
(Ord. No. 09-01, § 1, 1-6-2009) 
Sec. 20-36. - Violation; penalty. 
    Violation of any portion of this article constitutes a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(Ord. No. 09-01, § 1, 1-6-2009) 
Secs. 20-37-20-45. - Reserved.
