Secs. 22-54-22-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS AND AMENITIES 

Sec. 22-60. - Statement of policy. 
    It is the policy of the City of Eagle Pass to promote the adequate, efficient and safe use of public property within the city limits and in particular its sidewalks. To his end, this article provides for the installation and regulation of benches upon city sidewalks and other related amenities authorized by Vernon's Annotated Civil Statutes, Article 1085(c) for the convenience of the public in its use of the public streets and sidewalks for pedestrian or vehicle transportation. 
(Ord. No. 88-03, § 1, 4-5-1988) 
Sec. 22-61. - Administration and enforcement of article. 
    Except as specifically reserved for the city council in this article, other ordinances or the City Charter, the responsibility for the administration and enforcement of this article shall be a function of the city manager, his authorized representative or any official of the city which he may designate. All designations of authorized representatives, officials, standards or policies of the city manager as may be provided in this article shall be filed with the city secretary and with copies thereof furnished to each applicant for a permit hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 88-03, § 1, 4-5-1988) 
Sec. 22-62. - General authority and duty of city manager. 
    The city manager shall implement and enforce this article and may by written order establish such rules and regulations, not inconsistent with this article, as he determines are necessary to discharge his duty under or to effect the policies of this article. 
(Ord. No. 88-03, § 1, 4-5-1988) 
Sec. 22-63. - Establishment of rules and regulations. 
(a)  Before adopting, amending or abolishing a rule or regulation the city manager shall hold a public hearing on the proposal. 
(b)  The city manager shall determine the time and place of the hearing and, in addition to the notice required under Vernon's Annotated Civil Statutes, Article 6252-17, shall notify each permit holder and such other persons as the city manager determines are interested in the subject matter of the hearing. 
(c)  After the public hearing, the city manager shall notify the permit holder and other interested persons of his action and shall post an order adopting, amending or abolishing a rule or regulation on the official bulletin board in the City Hall for a period of not fewer than ten (10) days. The order becomes effective immediately upon expiration of the posting period. 
(Ord. No. 88-03, § 1, 4-5-1988) 
Sec. 22-64. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    City means the City of Eagle Pass, Texas, a home-rule city. 
    City manager means the person, his authorized representative, or its designated representative. 
    Public street means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way which is held by the city in fee or by easement or dedication when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel; provided the term "public street" shall not include any designated state or federal highway or road or any designated county road. 
    Roadway means that portion of a public street which is improved, designated or ordinarily used for vehicle travel, exclusive of the curb, beam or shoulder. In the event that "public street" includes two (2) or more separate roadways, "roadway" means each such roadway separately. 
    Sidewalk means that portion of a public street which is between the curb lines, or the lateral lines of a roadway, and the adjacent property lines and is improved and designed for or is ordinarily used for pedestrian travel. 
(Ord. No. 88-03, § 1, 4-5-1988) 
Sec. 22-65. - Operating authority required. 
    A person may not operate hereunder or make use of city sidewalks inside the city without obtaining a permit as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 88-03, § 1, 4-5-1988) 
Sec. 22-66. - Transferability of operating authority. 
    A biannual permit may not be transferred to another unless the holder files a written application for the transfer in the manner and containing the information prescribed herein and by the city manager and unless the transferee of said permit complies in all respects with the requirements for a biannual permit provided hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 88-03, § 1, 4-5-1988) 
Sec. 22-67. - Biannual permit granted by the city manager. 
    Before a biannual permit is granted, the application for the biannual permit must be approved by the city manager. The granting of a biannual permit by the city manager is contingent upon the applicant meeting all requirements set forth in this article and shall not be granted unless the city manager finds: 
(1)  That the improvement or facility will not be located on, extend onto, or intrude upon any portion of a roadway; 
(2)  That the improvement or facility will not be located on, extend onto, nor intrude upon any of the portion of a sidewalk which is needed for pedestrian use; 
(3)  That the design and location of the improvements include all reasonable planning to minimize its potential harm, injury or interference to the public in the use of the public streets and sidewalks; 
(4)  That the improvement or facility will not create any hazardous condition or obstruction of the vehicular or pedestrian travel upon the public streets or sidewalks; and 
(5)  That the service is required by the public convenience and necessity. 
(Ord. No. 88-03, § 1, 4-5-1988) 
Sec. 22-68. - Application for biannual permit. 
    To obtain a biannual permit, a person shall make application to the city manager in the manner prescribed by this section. The applicant must be the person who will own, control or operate the proposed improvements. An applicant shall file with the city manager a written, sworn application containing the following: 
(1)  The form of business of the applicant; if the business is a corporation or association, a copy of the documents establishing the business and the name, address and citizenship of each person with a direct interest in the business; 
(2)  Name, address and verified signature of the applicant; 
(3)  Description of any past business experience of the applicant and identification and description of any revocation or suspension of a franchise or permit held by the applicant or business before the date of filing the application; 
(4)  Documentary evidence from an insurance company, authorized to do business in the State of Texas, indicating a willingness to provide liability insurance required by this article; 
(5)  The location where he desires to place the subject improvements accompanied by a written authorization of the abutting fee property owners that the improvements may be located thereon; 
(6)  Detailed construction summaries showing the materials, type of construction and proposed manner of installation of the subject improvements; and 
(7)  Documentary evidence of payment of ad valorem taxes on the improvements to be used hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 88-03, § 1, 4-5-1988) 
Sec. 22-69. - Biannual permit investigation of application and approval. 
(a)  Upon receipt of an application for a biannual permit, the city manager shall conduct an investigation concerning public convenience and necessity and the following relevant factors: 
(1)  The character, experience and fiscal responsibility of the applicant; 
(2)  The number of other permits presently issued and in effect authorizing the establishment of improvements provided herein; 
(3)  The needs of the city and the adequacy of current improvements upon its public streets and sidewalks to meet those needs; and 
(4)  The effect of the issuance of a further permit hereunder for the establishment of other improvements upon city sidewalks and streets on traffic conditions, working conditions of existing permit holders, public mass transportation services and public safety. 
(b)  The applicant for a biannual permit has the burden of proving that the public convenience and necessity requires the issuance of the permit and that the applicant is qualified and financially able to provide the services proposed in the application. 
(c)  Within a reasonable time following the date of the application, the city manager shall hold a public hearing to consider whether a biannual permit should be granted. 
(d)  Upon approval of an application for a biannual permit, the city manager shall promptly issue the permit and incorporate in the permit such terms or conditions consistent with the policies herein set forth as he determines are necessary. 
(e)  An applicant may appeal a decision by the city manager denying a biannual permit to the city council by filing a written notice of appeal with the city secretary within ten (10) days of notification of the adverse decision. 
(Ord. No. 88-03, § 1, 4-5-1988) 
Sec. 22-70. - Renewal of biannual permit. 
(a)  A biannual permit may be automatically renewed upon application of the holder accompanied by a renewal service charge of five hundred dollars ($500.00) unless the city manager notifies the holder of his intention to deny the permit renewal based on his determination that: 
(1)  The holder is not in compliance with the permit and applicable provisions of this Code and other law; 
(2)  The holder is not fit, willing or able to continue to operate and maintain the public improvements authorized hereunder in accordance with the permit and applicable provisions of this Code, city manager regulations and other applicable law; or 
(3)  The public convenience and necessity does not require the continued service. 
(b)  If the city manager determines that a denial of a permit or a material change in the terms or conditions of the permit is required by the public convenience and necessity and not agreed to by the holder, or if a holder requests a material change in the terms or conditions of the permit not approved by the city manager, the city manager shall submit for consideration by the city council a written report containing his recommendations for denial or his recommendations for the proposed or requested change together with supporting findings of fact. Upon action being taken by the city council, the city manager shall issue a denial of permit renewal or renew the permit, as directed by the city council. In the case of renewal, he shall incorporate such changes as authorized by the city council. 
(c)  If the permit expires through no fault of the holder before a ruling on the approval or denial of the renewal, the permit holder may continue operating pending a final decision hereunder. The holder shall cease operation immediately upon final denial of the request for renewal by the city manager or city council as the case may be. 
(Ord. No. 88-03, § 1, 4-5-1988) 
Sec. 22-71. - Amendment, suspension and revocation of operation authority. 
(a)  Suspension and revocation of a permit. The following apply to the suspension or revocation of a biannual permit: 
(1)  The city manager may suspend or revoke a permit if he determines that the holder has: 
a.  Failed to comply with a correction order issued to the holder by the city manager within the time specified in the order; 
b.  Intentionally or knowingly impeded the city manager or any other law enforcement agency in the performance of its duty or execution of its authority; 
c.  Failed to comply with any of the provisions of this article; 
d.  Breached the terms of the permit; 
e.  Failed to pay city ad valorem taxes on any property of the holder used directly or indirectly in connection with the permit; or 
f.  Failed to pay a permit fee within thirty (30) days from the day it was due. 
(2)  A suspension of a permit does not affect the expiration date of the permit. 
(3)  After revocation of a permit, a holder is not eligible for a permit for a period of two (2) years. 
(b)  After suspension of a permit, a holder may file with the city manager a written request for reinstatement of the permit. The city manager shall inspect the operation of the suspended holder to determine if the deficiency causing the suspension has been corrected by the holder. After inspection, the city manager may reinstate the permit or deny reinstatement. 
(c)  An applicant may appeal a decision by the city manager suspending a permit to the city council by filing a written notice of appeal with the city secretary within ten (10) days of notification of the adverse decision. 
(d)  In any event and notwithstanding the foregoing, the city manager may, at any time with or without notice to the permittee, remove all or any part of any improvements for which a permit has been issued without liability therefor if the public convenience and necessity so require in the event of emergency or other lawful need by the city for access thereto, subject to the applicant's right of appeal as aforesaid. 
(Ord. No. 88-03, § 1, 4-5-1988) 
Sec. 22-72. - Permit fees. 
    Before the issuance of any permit under this article, the applicant shall pay to the city tax assessor/collector the sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00) to defray administrative expenses in the procession of such application. 
(Ord. No. 88-03, § 1, 4-5-1988) 
Sec. 22-73. - Public liability and property damage insurance-Required. 
    Before the granting of any biannual permit provided for herein shall become effective, the holder shall procure and furnish to the city manager, and thereafter keep in full force and effect, a policy of public liability and property damage insurance to be approved by the city manager, and issued in the minimum amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00). Every such policy shall insure the city against liability for any claimed losses of life or property or injuries of any type whatsoever which may arise from or in connection with any improvements installed pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. 88-03, § 1, 4-5-1988; Ord. No. 89-19, § 1, 10-20-1989) 
Sec. 22-74. - Provisions to be contained in insurance policies. 
    Every insurance policy required under this article shall contain an endorsement that cancellation of such insurance policy shall not become effective before fifteen (15) days after notice, in writing, to the city of such cancellation. 
(Ord. No. 88-03, § 1, 4-5-1988) 
Sec. 22-75. - Records to be kept by holder; reports to be made. 
    Each holder shall maintain at a single location records of its business and operations. The following specific requirements are hereby prescribed: 
(a)  Accurate records and receipts from operations and other operating information as may be required by the city manager, including, but not limited to, the location of all improvements and quality and construction materials used in same. Every holder shall maintain the records containing such information and other data required at a place readily accessible for examination at all reasonable times by the city manager. 
(b)  Each holder shall submit to the city manager upon request such annual and monthly reports concerning his service as the city manager determines necessary to evaluate the holder's operation. 
(c)  Every holder shall submit to the city manager or his authorized representative reports on all accidents occurring inside the City of Eagle Pass and arising from or in connection with the permit holder's operations which result in death or injury to any person or in damage to any vehicle or any other property exceeding the sum of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) within twenty-four (24) hours from the time of such occurrence. 
(Ord. No. 88-03, § 1, 4-5-1988) 
Sec. 22-76. - Payment of taxes. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every owner of the improvements used hereunder within the city to render for ad valorem taxes to the city all such equipment and improvements used in such business. Failure to render for and to pay such ad valorem taxes accruing upon same to the city before they become delinquent shall be good cause for revocation of the holder's permit. 
(b)  A holder's operation authority shall not be issued if any delinquent taxes are due the city upon any improvement for which such operating authority is sought, or if the owner thereof has failed to render same for ad valorem taxation. 
(c)  Prior to issuance of a holder's permit, the city tax assessor/collector shall examine the tax records of the city and ascertain whether or not the ad valorem taxes assessed by the city against the improvements and other equipment to be used in the business of the applicant have been fully paid. If such ad valorem taxes have not been paid, the city shall refuse to issue the applicant such license or renewal thereof until all of said ad valorem taxes have been paid. 
(Ord. No. 88-03, § 1, 4-5-1988) 
Sec. 22-77. - Improvement requirements and inspection. 
(a)  All minimum state requirements for size, material, construction standards, conditions and accessories for the improvements to be used by a holder hereunder shall be complied with and evidence hereof furnished to the city manager prior to the issuance of any permits authorized by this article. 
(b)  The city manager shall inspect each such improvement before it is placed in service, and at other times when determined to be necessary, for compliance with this article and regulations of the city. 
(c)  A holder shall make the improvements available for inspection when requested by the city manager. 
(d)  If a holder fails to make the improvements available for inspection or if the city manager determines that certain improvements are not in compliance with this article or regulations of the city, the city manager may order the improvements removed from service until they are made available for inspection and brought into compliance, all at the cost of the permit holder. 
(e)  If the city manager determines that inspection of the condition of the improvements by a technician is necessary, the holder shall pay the cost of the inspection. 
(Ord. No. 88-03, § 1, 4-5-1988) 
Sec. 22-78. - Violation of article; constitutionality of provisions; appeals. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, either by himself or agent, to knowingly perform any act prohibited by the terms of this article or in any way violate the provisions thereof. A separate violation is committed each day in which a violation occurs. Any person violating any provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined an amount not exceeding two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(b)  Prosecution for a violation under paragraph (a) does not prevent the use of other enforcement remedies available to the person charged with or the conduct involved in the violation. 
(c)  If any section, subsection, paragraph, subparagraph, clause, phrase, word, provision or portion of this article shall be held to be unconstitutional or invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, such holding or decision shall not affect or impair the validity of this article as a whole or any part thereof, other than the portion so held to be invalid. 
(d)  If a written request for an appeal hearing is filed with the city secretary within the ten-day limit, concerning any adverse decision made by the city manager under this article, the city council shall set a date for the hearing. The city council shall hear and consider relevant evidence offered by any interested person. The formal rules of evidence do not apply. The city council shall decide the appeal on the basis of a preponderance of the evidence presented at the hearing. The city council shall affirm, reverse or modify the action of the city manager by a majority vote; failure to reach a majority decision on a motion shall leave the city manager's decision unchanged. The decision of the city council is final as to administrative remedies. 
(Ord. No. 88-03, § 1, 4-5-1988) 
Sec. 22-79. - Public and governmental actions and functions of city. 
    The actions of the city in granting any permit authorized hereunder and in permitting the use of any public street for any purpose authorized herein pursuant to a permit issued hereunder are hereby declared to be public and governmental actions and functions of the city, exercised for a public purpose and matters of public necessity. 
(Ord. No. 88-03, § 1, 4-5-1988) 
Sec. 22-80. - Right to abate unlawful obstruction or use not impaired; political subdivision not required to obtain permit. 
    The provisions of this article shall not be construed to impair the right of the city or any other authorized person to abate or cause to be abated any unlawful obstruction or use of any public streets or sidewalks, nor to require any political subdivision of the state to obtain a permit to establish or maintain any improvement or facility which is otherwise authorized by law. 
(Ord. No. 88-03, § 1, 4-5-1988) 
Secs. 22-81-22-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - USE OF CITY-OWNED BUILDINGS, EQUIPMENT AND FACILITIES 

Sec. 22-91. - Multi-purpose center. 
    The City of Eagle Pass shall make available to its citizens the use and rental of the multi-purpose center, a city-owned facility, for noncity events and/or activities during noncity use periods. The city council hereby establishes the use of the multi-purpose center, and approves and adopts the user/rental schedule of fees to be assessed and collected by the city as set forth herein below in this section: 
(1)  All user/rental scheduled fees incurred herein shall be assessed upon all persons and entities requesting and/or receiving such services as well as their successors, assignors, executors, representatives, and heirs. 
(2)  The multi-purpose center user/rental schedule of fees shall be based on the following category: 
a.  Non-profit functions (i.e. church and educational organizations (graduations), fundraisers for non-profit organizations, etc.) the non-profit category users shall pay the sum of one hundred and fifty dollars ($150.00) for use of the multi-purpose center. Users will be responsible for the set-up, tear-down and clean-up of facility. Failure to do so will result in additional clean-up fees. A copy of the 501c3 will be required. 
(3)  The multi-purpose center business hours are from Monday through Friday from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. The multi-purpose center is available for lease during weekdays and weekends. The rental hours for day use shall be 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. from Sunday through Saturday. The evening rental hours shall be from Sunday through Saturday from 5:00 p.m. to 10:00 p.m. The city shall provide users one (1) free hour after the event to cleanup and remove any noncity property from the premises. The city shall provide those tables and chairs available at the multi-purpose center to those users requesting the same be provided for. 
(4)  Alcoholic beverages may not be served at the multi-purpose center. 
(Ord. No. 97-36, § 2, 12-2-1997; Ord. No. 99-13, § 1, 7-6-1999; Ord. No. 00-15, § 1, 5-9-2000; Ord. No. 02-27, § 1, 9-17-2002; Ord. No. 2016-29, § 3, 9-20-2016) 
Sec. 22-91.1. - Eagle Pass International Center for Trade. 
    The city hereby establishes the use of the International Center for Trade, herein known as the Trade Center, in accordance with the provisions as set forth herein below. 
(1)  [Reserved.] 
(2)  Lease for use of facilities. Written lease contract shall be required from all lessees of the Trade Center facilities and the city manager or designated representative is hereby authorized to execute such contracts on behalf of the city. The clauses and covenants of such written lease contract shall be legally binding as if they were a part of this ordinance and are hereby incorporated herein by reference as Exhibit A for all purposes. Verbal agreements to rent shall not be recognized under any circumstances, and the regulations contained in this chapter and the rental agreement, after acceptance, shall constitute the entire rental agreement and may not be varied or altered unless done so in writing and signed by authorized representatives of both parties. 
(3)  Payments under lease due and payable to city. All payments under a lease contract for use of the Trade Center shall be due and payable to the city. 
(4)  Sponsor's contract to be submitted with application for use. For the purpose of determining rental fees for use of the Trade Center, a certified copy of all contracts entered into by the sponsoring organization shall be submitted with the application for use. 
(5)  Deposit required prior to use. At the time of signing a lease contract for the use or rental of any of the Trade Center premises, the lessee shall deposit a sum of money of not less than fifty (50) percent of rental rate plus a maintenance deposit in the amount specified in the rental charges under subsection (7). Failure of the lessee to use the premises during the contracted lease period shall constitute a breach of contract; however, if the lessee cancels the lease contract three (3) months or more prior to the date of the contracted lease period, the lessee shall be refunded fifty (50) percent of the amount deposited with the city; but if the lessee cancels less than three (3) months prior to the date of the contracted lease period, the lessee shall receive no refund and the entire deposit shall be forfeited to the city. 
(6)  City may refuse to rent. Acting through the city manager or designated representative, the city hereby reserves the right to refuse to rent the facilities of the Trade Center to any individual or group not acting in the best interest of the public or the city. 
(7)  Rental charges generally. The rentals for the various attractions and purposes for which the trade center is rented shall be charged as herein provided. 
a.  Non-commercial uses (i.e. weddings, social/civic clubs, church/educational organizations, not-for-profit functions, etc.):

c.  Discounted rates. Non-commercial and commercial tenants using the property for the purpose of conventions, Monday thru Friday between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. will receive a fifty (50) percent discount on the rates listed above. Discount does not apply to maintenance deposit or any other uses listed on subsections below. For use of property beyond 5:00 p.m., payment shall be prorated at the aforementioned discounted rate. 
(8)  Rental charges for city-sponsored activities and uses not covered by approved fees. 
a.  There shall be no charge for city-sponsored activities or fundraising activities which will return ninety (90) percent of funds collected to the city. 
b.  Requests for use of any of the rooms for less than four (4) hours will be prorated according to the appropriate rate schedule under subsection (7). 
c.  Requests for the use of any facilities of the Trade Center not covered by the approved rental fees shall be presented to the city council for approval/disapproval. 
(9)  Free use prohibited. Minimum rental charges and highest bidded amounts shall be collected at all times and no free use thereof shall be permitted, extended or granted to any individual, organization or group, except as provided in this chapter. 
(10)  Renting on bids. An exception to the basic rates established in subsection (7) above shall be made in the following circumstances: 
a.  Any person or organization wishing to use any of the Trade Center facilities on special occasions, including but not limited to December 24, December 25, or December 31, shall submit to the city manager or designated representative a sealed bid for the use of such facilities. Designation or exception of such special occasions shall be made by the city manager with sufficient time in advance to enable compliance with this section. 
b.  Sealed bids shall be submitted on a form which will be available at the Trade Center business office. The bid shall include a cashier's check, payable to the city, for one-half (1/2) of the amount of the bid. Such check shall serve as a deposit on and be applied against the total rental to become due. The check of any unsuccessful bidder will be returned to the bidder. 
c.  All bids shall state, in addition to the amount of the bid, the name of the person or organization submitting the bid and the purpose and time for which the facilities are to be used. All bids must be received in the Trade Center business office on or before 4:00 p.m. of the day preceding six (6) months prior to the special occasion for which the facilities are sought to be rented. If the date immediately preceding such six-month period falls on a Sunday or a national or state holiday, such bid may be received on the next business day. 
d.  The premises and facilities sought will be rented to the person or organization making the highest bid, provided such bid is not less than the basic rate established in subsection (7). The city manager will reserve the right to reject any and all bids and to accept the bid which it considers to be the most advantageous. If no bids are received as specified in this section, then the regular rates for the facilities will prevail and the facilities will be rented on a first come, first served basis. 
(11)  Broadcasting or television performances, lectures, etc. No lessee of Trade Center facilities shall broadcast or televise any performance, lecture, concert, and/or public or private meeting by radio or television without the written consent of the city manager. If the requisite consent is given, the lessee shall furnish and install all equipment necessary for the broadcast and for the control booth, other than that furnished by the city manager or designated representative. The lessee shall remove all such equipment before 12:00 noon on the day following the performance, concert, lecture, and/or public or private meeting, or before 12:00 noon on the day following the last concert, lecture, performance, and/or public or private meeting, if a series thereof is provided for by the lease. If possession of the premises is to be surrendered by the lessor to some other tenant before 12:00 noon on the day following the termination of the lease referred to in this section, the lessee shall remove all such equipment immediately and before the time fixed for the surrender of the premises to such other tenant. Installation and removal of all such equipment shall be at the expense of the lessee and subject to the supervision of the city manager or designated representative. 
(12)  [Leasing for commercial purposes where tickets are sold.] Any person, group or organization leasing the Trade Center for commercial purposes where tickets are sold for admission shall pay to the Trade Center an amount equal to ten (10) percent of the total ticket sale in addition to any other payment required by the city. This revenue shall be deposited in a special fund which shall be dedicated to the purchase of capital items, landscape improvements, facility improvements and repairs, and conference equipment. 
(13)  Sale of merchandise generally. 
a.  The use of any portion of the Trade Center by any individual, firm or corporation for the purpose of selling merchandise is hereby prohibited, except that the selling of merchandise by display, exhibit or presence of the merchandise under the sponsorship of arts clubs and associations, charitable organizations and hotel conventions, restaurant shows, and activities of a similar nature shall be excepted from such prohibition and shall be permitted upon the approval of the city manager or designated representative. 
b.  Any person selling programs, novelties, souvenirs, records, tapes or literature in relation to, or in conjunction with, a function at the Trade Center shall pay to the Trade Center a commission of ten (10) percent of the gross sales of such items. 
c.  Any exception to the provisions of this section must be approved by the city manager and an appropriate rental shall be set by the city manager not to be less than ten (10) percent of gross sales. 
(14)  Concessions. 
a.  The city reserves the right to operate concessions for the sale of food, drinks, programs, novelties, souvenirs, etc. If the city permits a user the right to operate the concession, said user shall pay to the city an amount equal to fifteen (15) percent of all concession sales. 
b.  No person attending a commercial function at the Trade Center shall be permitted to bring any food, beverage or ice into rented areas. 
c.  When and if the city rents the buildings of the Trade Center or any parts thereof to a lessee for noncommercial functions where no admission charge or registration fee is collected by such lessee, the lessee shall be permitted to furnish to its guests food and other items, except those types of food and drink sold by the concessionaire. 
(15)  Catering services. Only catering services that pay the three hundred fifty dollar ($350.00) caterer's bond shall be allowed to provide catering services at the Trade Center. The caterer's bond must be paid to the city prior to the caterer's first event at the Trade Center. 
(16)  Time limit on occupancy. All lessees shall limit their occupancy of the Trade Center by persons or property to the time set out in the lease contract. 
(17)  Establishment of insurance requirements. The city council shall establish all insurance requirements pertaining to the use of the Trade Center and its premises. 
(18)  Tenants to indemnify city. All tenants of the Trade Center shall hold the city harmless from any and all liabilities for any claims resulting from their rental or use of the premises and shall indemnify the city in case of any claims resulting from their operations or occurring during their occupation of the premises, and all rental contracts shall specifically include such provisions. 
(Ord. No. 06-11, § 1, 6-20-2006; Ord. No. 06-19, § 1, 8-22-2006; Ord. No. 07-08, § 1, 3-19-2007; Ord. No. 2011-04, § 1, 3-22-2011) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2011-04, § 1, adopted March 22, 2011, set out provisions amending subsection 22-91.1(g). To maintain existing subsection numbering, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as subsection 22-91.1(7).

(Ord. No. 97-36, § 4, 12-2-1997; Ord. No. 99-13, § 1, 7-6-1999; Ord. No. 04-22, § 1, 7-21-2004; Ord. No. 04-36, § 6, 10-18-2004; Ord. No. 07-22, § 1, 10-9-2007; Ord. No. 2016-08, § 1, 2-2-2016; Ord. No. 2016-29, § 4, 9-20-2016; Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 5-2-2017; Ord. No. 2018-17, § 2, 8-7-2018; Ord. No. 2019-01, § 1, 1-16-2019) 
Sec. 22-93. - City manager's authority to reduce or waive fees. 
    The city manager is authorized to reduce or waive any of the user/rental scheduled fees for city-owned buildings, equipment, and facilities established by ordinance of the city council herein, if the city manager determines that such lower fees or waiver are in the best interests of the city and are necessary: 
(1)  To attract unique events that would bring special prestige to the city, showcase the city's economic, cultural and professional opportunities, or promote domestic or international tourism to the city; or 
(2)  To attract community-wide events that would encourage civic involvement and/or provide a special economic benefit to the city; or 
(3)  To assist the City of Eagle Pass or other government agency; or 
(4)  To assist a non-profit organization that is having a co-sponsored event with the city; or 
(5)  To assist a person or entity that but for a fee waiver would be unable to hold an event that will be of significant value to the city and open to the public. 
    The city manager may, upon his/her own initiative, or upon receipt of a request for a fee reduction or waiver, reduce the fees for an event that the city manager determines meets the criteria set forth herein, including a full waiver of the user/rental scheduled fees established by ordinance of the city council. The city manager may grant use of portions of the multi-purpose center or International Center for Trade at no charge if such events use the entire facility. 
    The city council may also reduce or waive fees, in its sole discretion provided the request otherwise complies with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 2, 8-18-2015)

Sec. 22-94. - Request for reduced fee or waiver. 
    Any request for a reduced fee or waiver must be submitted in writing to the city manager, by an authorized representative of an event that has submitted a reservation to use or rent a city-owned building or facility. 
(1)  The request for a fee reduction or waiver must include an address and contact information for the authorized representative of an event for the purpose of receiving notices. 
(2)  No request shall be approved for a reduced fee or waiver pursuant to section 22-93 for any event that has already executed a city center rental agreement or written lease contract for the International Center for Trade with the city. 
(3)  Any request for a reduced fee or waiver pursuant to section 22-93 must be on a form similar to the form at Exhibit A, and a completed form must be received by the city manager at least ninety (90) days prior to the proposed date of the event. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 2, 8-18-2015) 
Sec. 22-95. - Consideration of request. 
    The city manager may grant a request for a reduced fee or waiver only upon a written finding that the request meets at least the criteria set forth in sections 22-93 and 22-94 above. The city manager may reduce or waive up to one hundred (100) percent of the fee for the use of city-owned buildings, equipment, or facilities. In considering the request for a fee waiver or reduction in the fee, the city manager should consider charging an amount that would cover the city's personnel costs for the event. Within ten (10) days of the receipt of a request, the city manager shall provide a written notice of the decision to the applicant. No appeal may be taken from any denial of a request for a reduced fee or waiver. All events must be in compliance with the city's non-discrimination policy. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 2, 8-18-2015) 
Sec. 22-96. - Creation of special budget account. 
    To facilitate the promotion of greater civic involvement and economic development through the use and rental of city-owned equipment, buildings, or facilities, the city manager, or his/her designee, shall create a specific budget account designated for use in connection with events using city-owned equipment, buildings or facilities for which a reduced fee or waiver is granted. The total budget that may be utilized during a fiscal year by city manager to grant waivers or fee reductions may not exceed ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00); unless the city council increase the budgeted amount. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 2, 8-18-2015) 
Sec. 22-97. - Report to council. 
    The city manager shall prepare and file an annual report to council, which describes all events, equipment, buildings, or facilities granted fee reductions or waivers under section 22-93 of this chapter and detailing the fee reductions granted to such events. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 2, 8-18-2015) 
Sec. 22-98. - Waivers. 
    There shall be no waivers of any of the provisions of this article except as provided within this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 97-36, § 2, 12-2-1997; Ord. No. 99-13, § 1, 7-6-1999; Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 8-18-2015) 
Sec. 22-99. - Enforcement. 
    The City of Eagle Pass may enforce the provisions of this article by civil actions in courts of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 97-36, § 2, 12-2-1997; Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 8-18-2015)
